Project Description: Purpose: To support a painting and photography apprenticeship program for Boston-area teens. Additional Project Description: Apprentices will be mentored by professional artists and receive training in painting, composition, color theory, photography and digital editing. Studio courses will help students understand the creative process and develop fine art skills through a series of commissioned projects. Intended Beneficiaries: The apprenticeship program will benefit Boston-area teens and local businesses. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries acquire knowledge and skills in the arts.

To support a painting, photography, and video arts apprenticeship program for Boston-area teens. Apprentices will be mentored by professional artists and receive training in painting, composition, color theory, photography, sound engineering, digital editing, motion graphics/animation, and video production. Studio courses will help students understand the creative process and develop fine art skills through a series of commissioned projects.

To support a painting, photography, and video arts apprenticeship program for Boston-area teens. Apprentices will be mentored by professional artists and receive training in painting, composition, color theory, photography, sound engineering, digital editing, motion graphics/animation, and video production. Studio courses will help students understand the creative process and develop fine art skills through a series of commissioned projects. Project activities may take place virtually.

To support a painting, photography, and video arts apprenticeship program for Boston-area teens. Apprentices will be mentored by professional artists and will receive training in painting, composition, color theory, photography, sound engineering, digital editing, motion graphics/animation, and video production. Studio courses will help students understand the creative process and develop fine art skills through a series of commissioned projects. The program will introduce students to a variety of creative career opportunities.

To support a painting, photography, and video arts apprenticeship program for Boston-area teens. Apprentices will be mentored by professional artists and will receive training in painting, composition, color theory, photography, sound engineering, digital editing, motion graphics/animation, and video production. Studio courses will help students understand the creative process and develop fine art skills while delivering specific solutions through a series of commissioned projects for clients in both the public and private sectors.

To support a painting, photography, and video arts apprenticeship program for Boston-area teens. Professional artists will mentor apprentices who will receive training in painting, composition, color theory, photography, sound engineering, digital editing, motion graphics/animation, and video production. Studio courses help students understand the creative process by learning to develop fine art skills while delivering client-specific solutions through a series of commissioned projects.

To support a painting and photography apprenticeship program for Boston-area teens. The apprentices, participating in the Youth Arts Enterprise program, will be mentored by professional artists with an emphasis on the creation, exhibition, marketing, and sale of art work. Studio courses in painting and photography (both traditional and digital formats) will be offered.

To support a youth painting and photography apprenticeship program. Studio courses in painting and photography will be offered to under-resourced high school students providing them with access to arts education, cultural enrichment, and an entrepreneurship program to develop creative skills under the tutelage of professional artist mentors.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support AFH's Painting/Mural and Photography Studios. Through paid apprenticeships, underserved youth will receive studio instruction in painting, photography, and mural arts; students also will gain business skills in the arts such as coordinating and marketing art exhibitions, making presentations to corporate clients, and working in a team environment.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support "Youth-Run Arts Micro-Enterprise", a visual arts education program. Through paid apprenticeships, underserved youth will receive studio instruction in painting, photography, and web design.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support the "Youth-Run Arts Micro-Enterprise" program. Through paid apprenticeships, underserved youth (ages 14 to 18) will receive studio instruction in painting, photography, sculpture, murals/set design, silk-screen, and graphic design.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support the Youth-Run Arts Micro-Enterprise program. Through paid apprenticeships, underserved youth (ages 14 to 18) will receive studio instruction in painting, photography, sculpture, murals/set design, silk-screen, and graphic design.

To support expansion of the Youth-run Arts Micro-enterprise program. Through four-year paid apprenticeships, young people aged 14 to 18, primarily from low-income neighborhoods in Boston, receive studio instruction in painting, architecture, photography, sculpture, murals and theatrical set design, silk-screening, and graphic design.
In recognition of programming that develops leadership and entrepreneurial skills in at-risk youth through paid job training and employment in the arts.

Discipline / Field: Creative Links: Positive Alternatives for Youth
Project Description: To support a Creative Links project to provide positive alternatives for youth. The partnership brings together Grand Circle Travel and the Department of Public Health for Artists for Humanity s City Teens Design Company. More that four hundred youth, ages 14 to 18, will learn silk screening and other graphic arts, as well as business skills related to the field of graphic design.

To support the expansion and stabilization of the City Teens Design Company program and plans for its replication in other cities, to create opportunities for at-risk teens to learn and apply artistic skills within a business context. Through its City Teens Design Company (CTDC), Artists for Humanity provides opportunities for at-risk youth to work with accomplished professional artists in the fields of visual arts, graphic design, ceramics and sculpture, photography, printmaking and scenic and set design to produce creative concepts and products that can be marketed to the public. This project is designed to stabilize CTDC by expanding the disciplines taught into self-sustaining, professional "micro-enterprise" studios that will work in conjunction with a marketing department to make each studio economically viable. Stabilization will include increasing the base of paid student-participants to 50 in 1998 and 60 in 1999, and expanding internal marketing capabilities. In addition, in 1998 leadership of the CTDC will collaborate with Boston Public Schools and work to identify leaders in other cities who may wish to replicate the project. CTDC has demonstrated success in commercial ventures including a contract with The Gillette Company to design book covers celebrating Black History and Hispanic Heritage Months; a

Organization Name: Arts & Business Council of Greater Boston, Inc.
Project Description: To support pro bono legal consulting and educational workshops for artists and arts organizations. Legal services and training currently available in Boston will be expanded to serve a multistate area, including Connecticut. The professional development workshops will be focused on legal topics such as copyright, estate planning, and insurance.

Purpose: To support staffing and administrative costs for professional development programs with a focus on equity, diversity, and inclusion. Additional Project Description: The programs will include networking and professional development opportunities focusing on arts administrators of color, as well as a series of equity, diversity, and inclusion workshops for organizational leaders. Workshops will be videotaped, livestreamed, and archived. Intended Beneficiaries: The services included in this project will benefit arts administrators in the greater Boston area, with a focus on connecting arts administrators of color. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation's cultural infrastructure.
To support general operating costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

To support professional development programs with a focus on equity, diversity, and inclusion. The project will include online networking and professional development opportunities for arts administrators of color; a series of equity, diversity, and inclusion trainings for organizational leaders; as well as promotion and messaging training for underserved arts groups.

To support professional development and capacity-building programs with a focus on equity, diversity, and inclusion among arts administration and audiences. The project will provide networking and professional development opportunities for arts administrators of color; a series of equity, diversity, and inclusion trainings for organizational leaders; and promotional campaigns to reach underserved audiences.

To support professional development and capacity building programs in the arts. Arts administrators will have opportunities to participate in workshops and other programming centered on encouraging ethnic diversity in the arts. The project will focus not only on diversifying those who work in the arts, but also those attending arts programming. Convenings and professional development activities will be scheduled with the intention of strengthening the effectiveness of partner organization Network for Arts Administrators of Color (NAAC Boston). To improve diversity, a collaborative promotional campaign with the City of Boston will be developed to reach out to people from communities that have been historically underrepresented in arts audiences.

To support a diversity and inclusion initiative. The initiative will provide professional development and services designed to improve arts administration skills, organizational leadership strategies, and audience engagement efforts to better reflect the racial, ethnic, and socioeconomic diversity of greater Boston. Promotional campaigns created in partnership with key community stakeholders will reach underserved audiences and address barriers to participation including access and affordability.

To support the ArtsBoston Audience Initiative. A database including information about the region's art audiences will serve as a springboard for technical assistance and professional development activities, including convening and workshops, for area artists and arts organizations.

To support the third phase of the Berkshire Audiences Initiative, in consortium with the Berkshire Taconic Community Foundation. This project will identify trends from the data collected in Phases I and II to create the first data-driven portrait of cultural participation in the Berkshires Region to help organizations understand their existing audiences, broaden and increase those audiences, and improve marketing effectiveness.
To support a redesign of the ArtsBoston.org and BosTix.org websites. The project will help to make cultural events more affordable, and forge new partnerships to reach audiences more effectively.

To support the expansion of the ArtsBoston.org and BosTix.org Web sites. The strategic online initiatives will provide the public with greater access to information about arts activities in the region at affordable ticket prices.

To support Arts Boston Summer Sizzle, an initiative to promote the new Internet-based comprehensive online arts calendar. The services will provide the public with greater access to information about arts activities in the region at affordable ticket prices.
To support BosTix.com and other internet-based initiatives. The services will provide the public with greater access to information about arts activities in the region at affordable ticket prices.

To support SmartMarketing Services. A range of technical assistance programs will serve to enhance the marketing capacity of Boston performing arts companies through such resources as cooperative print advertising discounts, shared mailing lists, and professional development workshops.
To support the development of Tickets Today. The program will provide online ticketing services and training to improve Boston's theater, dance, and music organizations' marketing and sales.

To support "Aspect: The Chronicle of New Media Art," a bi-annual DVD publication of works of time-based contemporary art. The volume, titled "Hi-Tech," will present five to 10 time-based works accompanied by audio commentary by a curator or critic; "Hi-Tech" will survey artists who have adapted emerging technologies to suit their artistic goals.

Purpose: To support an annual convening of designers and allied professionals to promote design practices that advance equity in the built environment. Additional Project Description: The convening will bring together design practitioners, academics, nonprofit leaders, students, researchers, funders, and community organizers who work in the field of community-engaged design. The conference will feature presentations, panel discussions, workshops, mentorship/networking, and professional development opportunities to support knowledge sharing and capacity building around design projects that support equity in American communities. Intended Beneficiaries: The convening will benefit designers and practitioners from related fields from across the United States. Intended Outcome: Arts leaders develop professional skills and strategies.
To support the translation from Italian of selected poems by Andrea Zanzotto. Born in a small village in northern Italy in 1921, Zanzotto has become one of the most important living Italian poets.

Purpose: To support staff salaries and teaching artist fees for free music education programs for youth. Additional Project Description: Students will participate in year-long performance ensembles and free music instruction, including music technology, keyboard, and music theory. In addition, students will have the opportunity to participate in master classes taught by visiting artists and will have access to the PULSE Music Method, an online music education portal. Intended Beneficiaries: Students from across the Boston area in elementary, middle, and high school will benefit from the program. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries acquire knowledge and skills in the arts.

To support faculty costs and artist fees for the Berklee City Music Preparatory and High School Academy music education programs. Students from underserved communities will participate in performance ensembles and free music instruction, including music technology, keyboard, and music theory. Students will have the opportunity to participate in master classes taught by visiting artists and will have access to the PULSE Music Method, an online music education portal.

To support the Berklee Beantown Jazz Festival. The free, multiple-stage outdoor event will showcase renowned artists from the contemporary jazz, Latin, blues, and soul genres. Additional project programming may include interactive educational activities and instrument playing, music listening sessions for children, and a guided cultural walking tour of Boston's South End which draws from the memories of musicians, club owners, and former residents of the neighborhood.

To support the Berklee BeanTown Jazz Festival. The free, multiple-stage outdoor event titled Jazz: A Peace Supreme will showcase world-renowned contemporary artists from the jazz, blues, and soul genres. Ancillary programming may include interactive educational activities and instrument playing, children's activities, and a guided High Notes of Jazz walking tour of Boston's South End neighborhood.

To support the expansion of the Boston Conservatory Program for Students on the Autism Spectrum. The assessment tool is the required product. The project will help preschool to early elementary-aged youth learn basic musical skills, develop gross and fine motor skills, provide children and their families a social experience through music, and provide the instructors with new pedagogical skills and experience teaching in an early childhood musical setting. The program will be team-taught by specially trained music education graduate students and experts in the fields of music and autism using a repertoire of original compositions created by the instructors. To encourage ongoing learning, families will receive a CD of songs from class to play at home.

To support the Berklee BeanTown Jazz Festival. The free multiple-stage outdoor event titled Jazz: The Voice of the People will showcase contemporary artists from the jazz, Latin, blues, and soul genres. Ancillary programming may include interactive educational activities and instrument playing, music listening for children, and a guided High Notes of Jazz Walk tour of the South End neighborhood. Featured festival performers may include Fernando Brandao, Sean Jones, Dianne Reeves, Randy Runyon, George Russell, Jr., and Esperanza Spalding.
To support the Berklee BeanTown Jazz Festival. The free outdoor event themed "Jazz: The Global Ambassador" will feature internationally renowned musicians.

To support the Berklee BeanTown Jazz Festival in Boston's South End. The 2013 outdoor festival is titled "Jazz: The Next Generation" and will feature an educational outreach program on the role of the jazz mentor and the importance of the apprenticeship model in training jazz musicians.

To support the Berklee BeanTown Jazz Festival. The 2012 outdoor festival "Celebrate Women in Jazz" will include free performances from renowned musicians including Geri Allen and JoAnne Brackeen; as well as educational events, multi-media installations, and live internet streaming of interviews with female jazz musicians.

To support the Berklee BeanTown Jazz Festival in the City's South End, in consortium with JazzBoston. In a partnership with JazzBoston, the festival will be programmed around the theme "Celebrate Global Music and Nature" and will include jazz and world music artists in performances, educational events, entertainment activities for families, and an interactive jazz-related installation.

To support the Berklee BeanTown Jazz Festival in consortium with JazzBoston, Inc. The festival programming will highlight New Orleans' role as the incubator of jazz and celebrate the city's diversity reflected in music, the foods and crafts, and through the participants.

Category: National Arts and Humanities Youth Program Awards
Project Description: In recognition of the Berklee College of Music (Berklee City Music), for their work in bringing year-round (after-school, in-school, Saturdays and summer) tuition-free music education to at-risk middle and high school students.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support the Faculty Outreach program, as part of the college's City Music Boston outreach program.

To support e-Sharp, a consortium project. Designed to provide students with opportunities to learn from experienced professional musicians and visiting artists, the Berklee City Music after-school program will be replicated in the District of Columbia in partnership with the Community Preservation and Development Corporation.
To support a conference and related publication. The conference will engage educators and practitioners in developing new strategies for design education and design practice.

Purpose: To support a production of mixed repertory dance works by Boston Ballet. Additional Project Description: Performances will include works by choreographers such as George Balanchine, Stephen Galloway, and Jiri Kylian and will take place at the Citizens Bank Opera House. Intended Beneficiaries: Audiences in the greater Boston area will benefit from the array of choreographic voices in this ballet and contemporary dance production. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.
To support general operating costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

To support Full On Forsythe, a repertory evening of dance works by William Forsythe. Works to be performed include Playlist (EP), Blake Works I, and a revival of Pas/Parts 2018. Blake Works I is a work for 21 dancers and is set to 7 songs by British electro-pop musician James Blake, and Pas/Parts 2018 is a piece in which dancers shape time with syncopation, melody, and musicality. Performances will take place at the Boston Opera House.

To support Parts In Suite, a performance program featuring repertory dance works. The dance works featured in the program may include William Forsythe's "Pas/Parts 2016," Justin Peck's "In Creases," and Jorma Elo's "Bach Cello Suites." For Peck's and Elo's works, the ballets will feature live musical performances by piano and cello soloists. Forsythe's piece includes a recorded electronic score by Thom Willems. Performances will take place at the Boston Opera House.

To support the presentation of "Artifact," by choreographer William Forsythe. The company will perform the full four-act version of the piece. With participation of Forsythe, stagers will set the piece on the company, giving dancers the opportunity to work directly with the choreographer. Dana Caspersen, Nicholas Champion, and Richard Siegal may appear in major non-speaking parts. Other artists associated with Forsythe and this particular work include stagers Kathryn Bennetts and Noah Gelber, technical coordinators Dietrich Kruger and Tanja Ruhl, and pianist Margo Kazimirska. The work will be performed at the Boston Opera House.

To support a repertory program featuring works by Karole Armitage, Yury Yanowsky, Jose Martinez, and Norbert Vesak. Armitage has blended the neo-classical and avant-garde in dances since the 1970s, and her new work will incorporate these elements. Yanowsky has choreographed many works for the company and school, but this will be his first mainstage production. The company will perform "Resonance," by Martinez, director of Spain's Compania Nacional, which is a previously commissioned work by Boston Ballet and is set to music by Listz. Vesak's "Belong Pas de Deux," from his full length "What to do till the Messiah Comes" (1973) will be a premiere for Boston Ballet. Vesak was a Canadian artist (1936-90) who had a penchant for rock music and social issues. All performances will take place at the Boston Opera House.

To support the presentation of the Edge of Vision repertory program. The program will feature a newly commissioned work by resident choreographer Jorma Elo, the revival of Helen Pickett's "Eventide" (2008), and one additional ballet. Elo received his first commission by Boston Ballet in 2002 ("Sharp Side of Dark"), and has gone on to create works for several other ballet companies. Selections from Bach's solo cello suites will accompany Elo's new work, with the music performed live. Elo also often designs the costumes for the ballets, and has become known for his use of space, sculptural movements, lighting effects, and choice of music and sound elements in his ballets. Helen Pickett, a former dancer from William Forsythe's Ballet- Frankfurt, originally created "Eventide" for Boston Ballet. "Eventide" will be revised and will use music that is Indian or Indian-influenced by composers Philip Glass, Ravi Shankar, and Jan Garbarek. The works will be presented at the Boston Opera House.

To support the presentation of Jiri Kylian's "Bella Figura," the company premiere of Jorma Elo's "C. to C. (Close to Chuck)," and the world premiere of a commissioned neo-classical ballet by Jose Martinez of Spain's National Dance Company. The works will be part of the company's 50th anniversary celebration. Artistic Director Mikko Nissinen has made performances of Jiri Kylian (former artistic director of Nederlands Dans Theater) ballets a specialty of the company, and has established Jorma Elo as a resident choreographer. Nissinen continues to seek out emerging choreographers like Jose Martinez, who will make his North American debut as a choreographer at Boston Ballet.

To support the presentation of an evening of ballets by choreographer Jiri Kylian including Wings of Wax (1997), Tar and Feathers (2006), and Symphony of Psalms (1978). Symphony of Psalms will be accompanied by the Boston Ballet Orchestra and Boston's New World Chorus; pianist Tomoko Mukaiyama will perform the live improvisations that are integral to the Tar and Feathers score; and Wings of Wax alternates courtly Baroque with the music of Philip Glass and John Cage.

To support performances of Jerome Robbins' 1944 ballet, "Fancy Free," at the Boston Opera House. The ballet will be accompanied by the Leonard Bernstein score, performed live by the Boston Ballet Orchestra.

To support the presentation of choreographer Jerome Robbins' ballets "Antique Epigraphs" and" Afternoon of a Faun" at the Boston Opera House. Artistic director Miko Nissinen has renewed the company's emphasis on the Balanchine and Robbins canon and the importance of neo-classicism as the foundation of contemporary ballet which was largely influenced by the work of Robbins.

To support the presentation of Apollo, choreographed by George Balanchine, during the company's first season at The Boston Opera House. The accompanying Stravinsky score will be performed live by the Boston Ballet Orchestra under music director Jonathan McPhee.
To support the presentation of JEWELS, by choreographer George Balanchine. The work will be performed at the Citi Performing Arts Center/Wang Theater.
To support the presentation of choreographer Antony Tudor's classic 1937 work, Dark Elegies. The work will premiere at the Wang Theatre in Boston.
To support the staging of "Polyphonia," a work by choreographer Christopher Wheeldon. The ballet will premiere at The Wang Theatre.
To support the commissioning and staging of a new work by choreographer Mark Morris. The work will premiere at the Wang Theatre.

To support the presentation of "Falling Angels," created by choreographer Jiri Kylian. Falling Angels, for eight women, is set to Steve Reich's Drumming, Part 1, a study in musical minimalism for a drum ensemble.
To support the presentation of Lady of the Camellias, choreographed by Val Caniparoli. The three-act ballet will be presented at The Wang Theatre, and will be included in outreach programs.

To support the presentation of "Romeo and Juliet" by Dutch choreographer Rudi van Dantzig. The production will be presented at the Wang Theatre and will include a variety of educational outreach programs.
To support the revival of a ballet by Christopher Wheeldon. The work will be performed at the Wang Theatre and receive a total of 12 performances.
To support the creation and presentation of a new work by choreographer Daniel Pelzig. The piece will be created to Samuel Barber's Concerto for Violincello and Orchestra.

To support staging of Michael Corder's "Danses Concertantes." The piece, set to music by Igor Stravinsky, will be part of a repertory program scheduled for the spring portion of Boston Ballet's 1999-2000 season.

Purpose: To support performances of Iphigenie en Tauride. Additional Project Description: The performances will be offered both as a livestream and in person at the GBH Calderwood Studio, a television studio associated with WGBH Public Television. Featured artists will include soprano Wendy Bryn Harmer as Iphigenie and tenor William Burden as Pylade. Intended Beneficiaries: Performances will reach in-person audiences in Boston, and international audiences through the digital streaming platform. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support performances of Handel's Amadigi di Gaula. Additional Project Description: The production will take place at GBH's Calderwood Studio, a television studio which can be uniquely configured for in-person performances and will allow for livestreaming of one performance within the production cycle. The cast will feature countertenor Anthony Roth Costanzo, soprano Amanda Forsythe, mezzo-soprano Daniela Mack, and soprano Camille Ortiz. The creative team will include director Luisa Muller and live stream director Matthew Principe. The company presents opera using period instruments as well as period-informed performance practices. Intended Beneficiaries: Performances will reach in-person audiences in Boston, and international audiences through the digital streaming platform. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation’s cultural infrastructure.

To support virtual streamed performances of Handel’s Giulio Cesare, Beethoven’s Fidelio, and Monteverdi’s L’incoronazione di Poppea and the creation of accompanying online programming. Streamed content will include both archival operatic productions and new content designed and created to enhance the audience’s virtual experience. New content may comprise director's cuts, concert talks, conversations with artists, and documentary short films about making of an opera. Two full archival opera productions will be available to virtual subscribers (Giulio Cesare and Fidelio). Additionally, highlights of the L’incoronazione di Poppea production will be released and available admission-free to audiences via the streaming platform Boston Baroque Live.

To support online streaming of archival opera video and audio, and planning costs for a period-instrument production of Handel's Ariodante. Archival video and audio of a period-instrument Baroque or Classical opera will be released to the public via online streaming in spring 2020.

To support a period-instrument production of L'incoronazione di Poppea (The Coronation of Poppea) by Claudio Monteverdi with related community engagement programming. The production will utilize a new performing version created by Music Director Martin Pearlman. First performed in 1643, the work was one of the first to derive its plot from a historical subject—the Roman emperor Nero's illicit love for the ambitious courtesan Poppea. Community engagement activities will include free programs for children and families and a pre-performance talk. In addition to Pearlman serving as conductor, the creative team will include Tara Faircloth (stage director), Amanda Forsythe (soprano), Anthony Roth Costanzo (countertenor), and Ryan Belongie (countertenor). Two performances will take place at the New England Conservatory's Jordan Hall in April 2019.

To support a new production of Mozart's "Die Zauberflote" (The Magic Flute). The semi-staged production will be performed with period instruments and will utilize technology and video projections. The creative team may comprise stage director Mark Streshinsky and costume designer A.T. Jones  Sons, The production may feature tenor Nicholas Phan, soprano Leah Partridge, bass Gustav Andreassen, and soprano So Young Park. Performances also will feature one of only two keyed glockenspiels in the world, built for period performances by organ builder Robin Jennings. As many as two performances at New England Conservatory's Jordan Hall will take place in the spring of 2016. Additional audiences may be reached through recordings and broadcasts.

To support a new production and recording of Monteverdi's "Il Ritorno d'Ulisse in Patria." The semi-staged production and first recording of Martin Pearlman's version of the work, performed with period instruments, will be part of the 40th anniversary season. The creative team will comprise conductor Martin Pearlman, director Mark Streshinsky, and recording producer and editor Thomas C. Moore. Performances may feature tenor Fernando Guimaraes (Ulisse), mezzo-soprano Jennifer Rivera (Penelope), mezzo-soprano Leah Wool (Minerva), mezzo-soprano Abigail Nims (Melanto), tenor Aaron Sheehan (Telemaco), tenor Daniel Shirley (Eurimaco), tenor Daniel Auchincloss (Eumete), tenor Marc Molomot (Iro), and counter-tenor Christophe Lowrey (L'humana fragilita/sailor).

To support performances of Beethoven's Symphony No. 9 on period instruments with related educational activities. In celebration of the 40th anniversary season, plans include two first-time Boston Baroque performances of Beethoven's last symphony in Jordan Hall at the New England Conservatory, a free concert at the Strand Theatre, pre-concert lectures, school workshops, and a free open dress rehearsal.

To support performances of "Les Indes Galantes" ("The Gallant Indians") by Jean-Philippe Rameau. The production will feature a period orchestra, up to seven vocal soloists coached in the French-baroque style, modern dancer, and choreographer Marjorie Folkman.

To support performances of Requiem in C Minor (1815) by Maria Luigi Cherubini and pre-concert lectures. The two performances of the work, using early music period instruments, will take place in New England Conservatory's Jordan Hall in Boston.
To support a production of Christoph Willibald Gluck's ALCESTE. The fully staged, period-style performances and a pre-performance lecture will be presented in the Cutler Majestic Theater.

To support performances of Monteverdi's 1610 Vespers during a multi-state tour in celebration of Boston Baroque's 30th anniversary season. In addition to concerts in Boston, the tour will include performances at the Los Angeles Music Center's Disney Hall, Ravinia Festival in Chicago, and Tanglewood Festival.

To support the commission and premiere performances of a new edition of Monteverdi's opera "Il Ritorno d'Ulisse in patria." Il Ritorno d'Ulisse represents the completion of a three-opera Monteverdi cycle during three successive seasons in Boston, with L'incoronazione di Poppea having been performed in 2000 and L'Orfeo performed in 2001.

To support concert performances and the first recording of The Beneficent Dervish, a newly discovered, fairy-tale opera written by Mozart and his friends and colleagues in the final year of his life. The concerts will take place in Boston's Jordan Hall at New England Conservatory during 2001.

To support folklife festivals. The Boston Center for the Arts Will present So Sabi! 2000: The Third New England Cape Verdean Folklife Festival; and The Gede Festival: A Celebration of Haitian Culture and Spirituality celebrating the Center's collaborative programming with both communities in the Boston area.

Organization Name: Boston Center for the Arts, Inc.
Project Description: Purpose: To support staff salaries and documentation costs for residency programs for artists working in multiple disciplines. Additional Project Description: Residency programs will be offered for Boston-based artists working in visual arts, dance, theater, music, and other performing arts, as well as experimental artists and those working across multiple disciplines. Selected artists will be provided with time, space, and resources such as professional development opportunities, marketing and publicity services, and production support. Artists may present work developed during the residency to the public through exhibitions and performances, as well as offer artist talks, open rehearsals, or workshops. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit participating Boston-based artists. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation’s cultural infrastructure.

Organization Name: Boston Center for the Arts, Inc.
Category: American Rescue Plan (ARP) Grants to Organizations
Project Description: Purpose: To support personnel, facilities, and marketing expenses in response to and recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. Additional Project Description: The support will help the organization maintain operations during recovery from the devastating economic and health effects of the COVID-19 pandemic. Intended Beneficiaries: This assistance will benefit the organization’s constituency, such as arts workers, artists, and audiences. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation’s cultural infrastructure.

Organization Name: Boston Center for the Arts, Inc.
Project Description: To support an artist residency program for dance. Artists will receive stipends and studio space, as well as curatorial and marketing support. Artists may present work developed during the residency through performances or work-in-progress showings, as well as offer artist talks, open rehearsals, or workshops for the general public.

Organization Name: Boston Center for the Arts, Inc.
Project Description: To support performing and visual artists residencies and related activities. The residencies will be geared towards interdisciplinary art making, encouraging expression that is collaborative, participatory, and cutting-edge. Work accomplished in residencies will be eligible for Run of the Mills, a series of intermittent, short-duration exhibitions, performances, and events set in the Mills Gallery. Additional performing arts residencies will be available for small theater and dance companies.

To support the Premier Choir and Young Men's Ensemble, vocal music training programs for high school youth in the Greater Boston area. Young singers will be trained by professional musicians during weekly rehearsals and music theory classes in which students will learn sight-reading, rhythmic concepts, music terminology, vocal technique, and performance skills. Students will have opportunities to perform concerts with renowned professional orchestras and work with visiting artists and composers premiering commissioned works.

To support the Premier Choir and Young Men's Ensemble, providing rigorous vocal music training for high school youth in the Greater Boston area. Young singers are trained by professional musicians during weekly rehearsals and music theory classes in which students learn sight-reading, rhythmic concepts, music terminology, vocal technique, and performance skills. In addition, students are provided opportunities to perform concerts, tour, record, and work with composers premiering commissioned works. Both ensembles regularly appear with well-known soloists, conductors, and orchestras such as the Boston Pops, enabling the singers to perform with professional musicians.

To support the Premier Choir and Young Men's Ensemble. The programs will provide rigorous vocal music training for high school youth in the Greater Boston area. Young singers are trained by professional musicians during rehearsals and music theory classes in which students learn sight-reading, rhythmic concepts, music terminology, and vocal technique. In addition, students are provided opportunities to perform concerts, tour, record, and work with guest conductors and composers premiering commissioned works. The Premier Choir and Young Men's Ensemble are the Boston Children's Chorus' highest level choirs.

To support the Premier Choir and Young Men's Ensemble, providing rigorous vocal music training for high school youth. Young singers are trained by professional musicians year-round in music theory and choral performance, and are provided opportunities to perform, tour, record, and work with guest conductors and composers premiering commissioned works. The Premier Choir and Young Men's Ensemble are the Boston Children's Chorus' highest level choirs.

Category: National Arts and Humanities Youth Program Awards
Project Description: In recognition of the Boston Children's Chorus, an organization dedicated to educating children from different socioeconomic backgrounds in choir music, leadership, and performance.

To support the Seeds to Song Project. Young singers are trained year-round in choral music and perform in Concert Choir, Premier Choir, Young Men's Ensemble and the Choral Union, designed for singers with no previous music theory training.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support the Seeds to Song Project. Young singers are trained in choral music and participate in Concert Choir, Premier Choir, Young Men's Ensemble and the Choral Union, designed for singers with no previous music theory training.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support the Seeds to Song Project. A new choir, Choral Union, will be created and will provide weekly music training to a diverse group middle and high school students who possess vocal talent but little or no training in music theory.

To support a mixed-methods study exploring how collaborative artmaking by artists and local residents can improve community social cohesion. The study will investigate the Pao Arts Center's Residence Lab, a program that partners Asian-Pacific Islander artists with Boston Chinatown residents so they can use storytelling and the co-creation of artwork to shape the future of Chinatown and expand its cultural footprint. Researchers will rely mainly on ethnographic and qualitative methods such as interviews with artists, residents, and visitors; observations of Residence Lab workshops; and analyses of artistic products. In addition, the team will administer community health surveys on social cohesion, cultural identity, neighborhood wellness, and the arts' potential impacts on health.

To support the creation of a new work in collaboration with Lenora Lee Dance. The San Francisco-based company will create Convergent Waves, which will center on Boston's Chinatown history and the historical significance of the location of Boston Chinatown Neighborhood Center's Pao Arts Center. The work will highlight experiences of Asian Americans and their contributions to the region.
To support the staging and reconstruction of Murray Louis works for Boston Conservatory Dance Theater students. The Murray Louis works include Schubert Suite, Index, and Four Brubeck Pieces.

To support Of, By, and For the Dance Makers, a series of workshops and retreats that will provide technical assistance to dance artists in producing and presenting work. Activities will include fellowships for choreographers and their dancers to create new work during a creative/rehearsal retreat, individual consultations, and workshops.

To support Behind the Scenes: In Front of the Curtain Part II, a technical support service for Boston dance artists. Continued development and utilization of their Web and video expertise will help the field reach new audiences and document their work for preservation and marketing.

To support "Behind the Scenes: In Front of the Curtain," a project to help dance companies engage new dance audiences. The project will involve a creative retreat for two choreographers and their dancers, with additional funding to pay dancers during the rehearsal period; individual coaching on marketing and fundraising; and video workshops for members and non-Boston Dance Alliance (BDA) members, teaching participants how to edit video, transfer work to multiple platforms, market video, and post work Online; and optimizing the BDA's Web site.
To support the preservation of jobs that are threatened by declines in philanthropic and other support during the current economic downturn.

To support a comprehensive audience development plan and an expansion of information for the dance community. Boston Dance Alliance will conduct a survey, develop a "Dance Bill" program, and add video streaming to the Boston Dance Alliance Web site.

To support professional and artistic development opportunities for media artists in the New England region. Through a comprehensive media arts education program, works-in-progress screenings (Rough Cuts), and Meet the Director series, the Boston Film/Video Foundation provides a full range of services to its constituency.

To support professional and artistic development opportunities for media artists in the New England region. Through a comprehensive media arts education program, the New England Film and Video Festival, and works-in-progress screenings (Rough Cuts), the Boston Film/Video Foundation (BFVF) provides a full range of services to its constituency.

To support a comprehensive media arts education program. Open to the public, this initiative is designed to encourage personal vision, assist in the development of concrete skills, and foster relationships meant to strengthen and advance the production of film and video art works.

To support a comprehensive media arts education program. Open to the public, this initiative is designed to encourage personal vision, assist in the development of concrete skills, and foster relationships meant to strengthen and advance the production of film and video art works.

To support a comprehensive media arts education program. Open to the public, this initiative is designed to encourage personal vision, assist in the development of concrete skills, and foster relationships meant to strengthen and advance the production of film and video art works.

To support a comprehensive media arts education program which encompasses a wide range of classes, seminars, and workshops offered to a variety of students from the New England region. Classes include specific film instruction workshops ("Introduction to 16mm Film Production," "Narrative Screenwriting," "Advanced Cinematography"); hands-on video production courses ("Off-Line Editing," "Adobe Premiere"); and esthetic and appreciation seminars. In addition, BFVF provides the New England independent community with opportunities to meet and learn first-hand from some of the major figures in recent independent film production. Previous guests have included Kevin Smith, Charles Burnett, John Pierson, and Allison Anders. BFVF has also been a leader in the media literacy movement. Very soon, it will publish TV Eye, a curriculum on critical viewing and production to be distributed nationally, and, since 1991, BFVF, has worked with inner-city youth on learning how to read commercial media products and then how to master the technical skills to produce their own work.

Category: American Rescue Plan (ARP) Grants to Organizations
Project Description: Purpose: To support personnel expenses in response to and recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. Additional Project Description: The support will help the organization maintain operations during recovery from the devastating economic and health effects of the COVID-19 pandemic. Intended Beneficiaries: This assistance will benefit the organization’s constituency, such as arts workers, artists, and audiences. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation’s cultural infrastructure.
To support general operating costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

Category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act
Project Description: To support personnel costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

To support the creation and premiere of a new work by composers Devin Ferreira and Jacob Gunnar Walsh and related educational activities. The new work will be a multi-sensory concert experience featuring projected images accompanying a live performance of a new orchestral work. The composers will create music featuring 50 youth drummers and dancers with orchestra, while visual artists Ryan Edwards and Sam Okerstrom-Lang will create the images, which will be projected on the architectural structure of the Hatch Shell on Boston's Esplanade and the monuments and trees surrounding the seating area. Educational activities may include drumming workshops for school students.

To support a celebration of the African American Spiritual. In partnership with the New England Spiritual Ensemble, a commissioned work by composer Trevor Weston that employs African-American spirituals and narrated poetry, will serve as a platform for workshops and educational performances. Weston will compose two versions of his new work: a full version to be performed at the Hatch Memorial Shell on Boston's Esplanade and a chamber version for use in educational performances.

To support the commission and performance of a new work by composer Michael Gandolfi. Activities will include the composer working with students at the Conservatory Lab Charter School to create a new work for double orchestra that will be premiered by student and BLO musicians.

Purpose: To support artist and creative team fees for a production of Omar, a new opera by composers Rhiannon Giddens and Michael Abels. Additional Project Description: The new work tells the true story of Omar ibn Said, an enslaved man taken from his home in what is now Senegal and trafficked to South Carolina. Educational activities may include audience talkbacks with the artists and the production team, teacher guides, and library programs. Intended Beneficiaries: Performances and activities will benefit the artists and Boston-area audiences. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support artist fees and staff costs for a new production based on La Bohème by Giacomo Puccini. Additional Project Description: The well-known opera will be presented in reverse, starting with Act IV and ending with Act I, giving audiences an opportunity to hear the opera anew, beginning with death and ending in love. Educational activities in partnership with Boston Public Schools will provide high school students with study guides, backstage tours, pre-performance lectures, and final dress rehearsal tickets. Community activities in partnership with Boston Public Library will provide access to free programming, such as Concert in the Courtyard series performances and an Opera Night at the library. Performances will occur at Emerson Colonial Theatre. Intended Beneficiaries: Performances and activities will benefit the artists and Boston-area audiences. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation's cultural infrastructure.

To support a new production of Champion by composer Terence Blanchard and librettist Michael Cristofer. The jazz-infused opera examines the life of welterweight boxer Emile Griffith, a bisexual man of color in the mid- to late-20th century. Performances will be accompanied by community partnerships with organizations to create authentic conversations around the issues of racial injustice and discrimination against LGBTQ individuals.

Category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act
Project Description: To support personnel costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

To support a new production of Pagliacci by composer Ruggero Leoncavallo. The 19th-century opera examines the timeless subjects of love, relationships, betrayal, and women's agency and continues to resonate with 21st-century audiences.

To support the world premiere of Schoenberg in Hollywood, a new opera by composer Tod Machover and librettist Simon Robson. Austrian composer Arnold Schoenberg fled Nazi Germany in 1934 and found refuge in the United States, initially in Boston before settling in Los Angeles. The complex artist, teacher, and mentor considered composing film music, but he never did. The new opera examines what might have happened if one of the modern era's most serious classical composers had taken on the movie industry. The opera is scored for 3 singers, 12 instruments, and interactive electronics. With a goal of creating a production that is intricate and flexible while also being efficient and economical, the creative team will include the composer, librettist, stage director Karole Armitage, set designer Simon Higlett, with soundscapes and video installations by MIT Media Lab's Peter Torpey. Performances will take place at the Emerson Paramount Center in fall 2018.

To support the premiere of "The Nefarious, Immoral, But Highly Profitable Enterprise of Mr. Burke  Mr. Hare." The opera by composer Julian Grant and librettist Mark Campbell is part of the Opera Annex initiative, which presents fully staged chamber operas in unusual settings. The opera is based on the real-life 19th-century Scottish murderers William Burke and William Hare, who profited by killing members of the underclass and selling their bodies for medical students' anatomy studies. Community engagement programs will include pre-concert talks, Opera Night at the Boston Public Library, and the Signature Series.

To support the Opera Annex initiative. The initiative presents fully staged chamber operas in unusual settings. A fully staged production of "Greek" by composer Mark-Anthony Turnage at ArtsEmerson's Paramount Center will be presented in fall 2016. This retelling of the Oedipus myth set in London when Margaret Thatcher was prime minister will be accompanied by outreach programs exploring issues raised by the opera, such as civil unrest in times of economic repression. A piano/vocal score reading of "Schoenberg in Hollywood" by composer Tod Machover and librettist Simon Robson, examining the composer Arnold Schoenberg's life in the U.S. after his 1934 flight from Nazi Germany, will be presented in winter 2017. Community engagement programs such as pre-concert talks, Opera Night at the Boston Public Library, and the Signature Series - presentations in partnership with the Boston Museum of Fine Arts and other Boston cultural institutions - will be offered throughout fall 2016 and winter 2017.

To support the Opera Annex initiative. The commissioned librettos are required products. The initiative presents fully staged chamber operas in intimate settings. Project activities will include a production accompanied by community engagement events, a co-commission of "Naga" by Scott Wheeler, and a workshop presentation of BLO commissioned "Schoenberg in Hollywood" by Tod Machover and Leslie Epstein. The latter work examines the composer's life in the U.S. after his 1934 flight from Nazi Germany. In addition to performances, pre-concert talks and other outreach activities will occur.

To support the Opera Annex initiative, which presents fully-staged chamber operas in intimate settings. The project will include productions of "Lizzie Borden" by Jack Beeson, an American opera, and an annual Open House community engagement event. Performances will occur at the Boston Symphony Orchestra's Tanglewood facility and at the Castle at Park Plaza. The latter was originally built as an armory in the 1890s at the time of the Borden murders and is atmospherically suggestive of the opera's content. The cast will be directed by Christopher Alden with artistic direction by John Conklin.

To support the co-commission and North American premiere of James MacMillan's "Clemency," presented in a double bill with Franz Schubert's "Hagar's Lament." The former work will serve as a prologue for the latter work with a new orchestration commissioned by Boston Lyric Opera (BLO), Royal Opera House Covent Garden, Scottish Opera, and Britten Sinfonia that will bridge the two works.

To support the adaptation and remounting of the comic opera THE INSPECTOR by composer John Musto and librettist Mark Campbell, including outreach activities. Based on the play The Government Inspector by Nikolai Gogol, this production will expand the physical and orchestral elements, working with the original creative team to make the work accessible for larger opera houses.

To support the "Music! Words! Opera!" and "Vacation Week Institutes" education programs, in consortium with Wheelock College's Family Theatre. The programs will engage Boston students both in and out of school.

To support a new production of "Der Kaiser von Atlantis (The Emperor of Atlantis)" by Viktor Ullmann and a companion vocal chamber work by Richard Beaudoin to serve as a prologue. Death serves as both the historical and dramatic backdrop of Ullmann's 1943 opera which he composed while a prisoner in Theresienstadt.

To support the Vacation Week Institute for Teens: Exploring Opera: Tom Sawyer, in consortium with Wheelock Family Theatre. A collaborative program tying opera and theater together will offer in-depth training for students in acting exercises, vocal and movement improvisation, exploration of blocking, and scene rehearsals.
To support a new production of The Turn of the Screw by Benjamin Britten. Performances will be accompanied by community events through partnerships with area Boston cultural institutions.

To support the East Coast premiere of THE LITTLE PRINCE by composer Rachel Portman and librettist Nicholas Wright. The performances are expected to appeal to audiences of all ages and diverse backgrounds, attract first-time audiences, and involve and feature large numbers of children in the mainstage production.
To support a community residency and concert.
To support performances of Bizet's "Carmen." Two fully-staged, free, outdoor performances and related educational activities will reach an estimated 30,000 people in 2002.

To support the regional tour of a fuly-staged and costumed production of "The Magic Flute" by Mozart. Thirty six performances of a one-hour, abridged version of this opera will be targeted to family audiences, educators, and students (grades 3 to 7) in underserved, inner- city and rural communities throughout New England and New York during 2000 and 2001.

To support a new production of the opera "Akhnaten" by American composer Philip Glass. Demonstrating a commitment to 20th century opera, Boston Lyric Opera seeks to establish a place for this minimalist work in the standard repertory by programming it in the company's Egyptian theme season.

To support Boston Lyric Opera's move to the larger Shubert theater, audience expansion, and strengthening the Opera's infrastructure to meet the region's demand for more opera productions and educational programming.

To support a collective impact project to sustain and deepen the work of the Boston Public Schools Arts Expansion Initiative in high schools. The project will increase the number of graduates who meet Massachusetts Common Core Standards in art and build a foundation for further developing the effort in targeted schools. Schools, teaching artists, and partners will engage in professional development and provide new arts classes while partners in the community will secure financial support, track and analyze outcomes, and plan how to reach all Boston Public School students.

Purpose: To support youth orchestra programs in Boston. Additional Project Description: Boston String Academy will expand current youth orchestra programs in Boston’s Allston and Chinatown neighborhoods, offering programming at more schools. Students will receive daily ensemble instruction, with additional weekly private or semi-private lessons. The curriculum will include instruction in violin or cello, singing, musical terminology, movement, and music reading. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit K-2 students in the Allston and Chinatown neighborhoods of Boston. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries acquire knowledge and skills in the arts.

Purpose: To support concert programs of composers and performers typically underrepresented in classical music, with related educational activities. Additional Project Description: Repertoire may include Samuel Coleridge-Taylor's Petite Suite de Concert, Anthony Davis's You Have the Right to Remain Silent, and Gorecki's Symphony No. 3 "Symphony of Sorrowful Songs". Educational activities may include conversations with artists and scholars. Intended Beneficiaries: The performances will benefit audiences throughout New England. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support orchestra musician's and conductor's fees for performances of Benjamin Britten's "War Requiem" with related educational activities. Additional Project Description: The concerts will feature the orchestra led by conductor Sir Antonio Pappano. Intended Beneficiaries: The performances will be promoted to audiences throughout New England. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

Purpose: To support the Festival of Contemporary Music at Tanglewood Music Center. Additional Project Description: The festival, curated and directed by soprano Tony Arnold, pianist Stephen Drury, composer George Lewis, and cellist Astrid Schween, will feature chamber music and orchestral performances by resident musicians and guest artists. The festival also will include a concert presentation of composer George Benjamin's new opera "Lessons in Love and Violence." Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit the resident musicians, the composers whose works will be performed, and audiences in Western Massachusetts. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.
To support online performances. Titled BSO NOW, programs of chamber and orchestral music will be recorded in Symphony Hall and released online.

To support the Festival of Contemporary Music at Tanglewood Music Center. The festival, curated and directed by composer, pianist, and conductor Thomas Ades, will feature chamber music and orchestral performances by resident musicians and guest artists.

To support a series of performances featuring contemporary works composed by women with related educational activities. Repertoire to be featured may include works by composers Helen Grime, Chihchun Chi-sun Lee, and Anna Thorvaldsdóttir. Educational activities may include interactive and online programs through the Tanglewood Learning Institute.

To support the online Tanglewood Music Festival, an academy for advanced musical study. The training festival, curated and directed by composer, pianist, and conductor Thomas Adès, will feature previous concerts offered online to audiences worldwide by student musicians and guest artists. Professional development activities will include online master classes and discussions for students from remote locations across the country and world by faculty and guest artists.

Category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act
Project Description: To support personnel costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

To support the world premiere performances of works by composers Thomas Adès and Sebastian Currier with related community engagement activities. Adès will conduct the orchestra's performance of his Piano Concerto featuring pianist Kirill Gerstein as soloist. Music Director Andris Nelsons will conduct Currier's Violin Concerto featuring Latvian violinist Baiba Skride as soloist. Community engagement activities may include podcasts and pre-concert lectures.

To support the Festival of Contemporary Music at Tanglewood Music Center. The festival, curated and directed by composer, pianist, and conductor Thomas Adès, will feature chamber music and orchestral performances by resident musicians and guest artists.

To support the Festival of Contemporary Music at Tanglewood Music Center. The festival, curated and directed by composer, pianist, and conductor Thomas Ades, will feature chamber music and orchestral performances by resident musicians and guest artists. Repertoire will include works by Ades, Gerald Barry, Gyorgy Kurtag, Witold Lutoslawski, Conlon Nancarrow, and Poul Ruders.

To support concerts and events in celebration the 100th anniversary of Leonard Bernstein's birth. Repertoire may feature performances of Bernstein's Symphonies No. 2 ("The Age of Anxiety") for orchestra and piano and No. 3 ("Kaddish") for orchestra, chorus, boychoir, soprano, and speaker. Symphony No. 2 was commissioned by former music director Serge Koussevitzky and had its world premiere at Symphony Hall in 1949, conducted by Koussevitsky, with Bernstein as piano soloist. Educational activities may include film screenings, a community chamber music concert, and an archival exhibit.

To support a series of concerts featuring co-commissioned works in Boston and New York City with related educational activities. Composers to be featured will include Julian Anderson, George Benjamin, Sofia Gubaidulina, and Matthias Pintscher. Concerts will take place in Symphony Hall in Boston, and Carnegie Hall in New York City. Engagement activities will include Conversations with the Creators series, and Do You Hear What I Hear? series. Concerts will be broadcast live on WCRB-FM as well as available online on WGBH's BSO Concert Channel and on the BSO's website.

To support the Festival of Contemporary Music at Tanglewood Music Center. The festival, curated by Tanglewood alumni Kathryn Bates, Jacob Greenberg, and Nadia Sirota, will feature chamber music and orchestral performances by resident musicians and guest artists. Each of the curator's selections will reflect their musical influences and interests.

To support concerts and outreach activities exploring repertoire inspired by the works of William Shakespeare. In commemoration of the 400th anniversary of the author's death, Music Director Andris Nelsons will lead the orchestra in performances of both well-known and rarely-heard works by Dvorak, Mendelssohn, Prokofiev, Shostakovich, Strauss, and Weber and of newer compositions by Hans Werner Henze, Hans Abrahamsen, and George Tsontakis. Also planned is the Insights Series of chamber music performances, moderated panel discussions with the artists and composers, screenings of films of Shakespeare's work with original scores by composers such as Dmitri Shostakovich and William Walton, and online educational offerings.

To support the Festival of Contemporary Music at Tanglewood Music Center. The festival will feature chamber music and orchestral performances by resident musicians and guest artists. Works by a wide array of contemporary composers will be highlighted including the U.S. premiere of composer George Benjamin's "Dream of the Song" for orchestra, women's chorus, and countertenor soloist. Established composers will be engaged to curate the chamber music programs.

To support the Insights Series, an exploration of symphonic, ballet, and opera repertoire from the early 20th century with related educational and ancillary events. Guest conductors such as Vladimir Jurowski, Stephane Deneve, and Charles Dutoit will lead the orchestra in performances of works by Stravinsky, Prokofiev, Milhaud, Poulenc, and Debussy culminating in a concert performance of Polish composer Karol Szymanowski's rarely performed opera "King Roger." Also planned are Conversations with Creators, moderated discussions with key artists, and ancillary chamber music performances.

To support the Tanglewood Music Center (TMC)'s 75th anniversary through performances of newly commissioned and established works. In celebration, performances of newly commissioned works will take place at every TMC concert as well as during the week-long Festival of Contemporary Music. Composers including Michael Gandolfi and John Harbison will each curate one day of the festival.

To support Beethoven and the Piano, an initiative exploring the composer's works for piano and orchestra and related educational activities. Plans include a complete cycle of Beethoven's five piano concertos plus the Triple Concerto for Violin, Cello, and Piano during the course of three successive concert programs featuring conductor Christoph von Dohnanyi and pianist Yefim Bronfman at Symphony Hall. The Boston Symphony Orchestra also will partner with the New England Conservatory, the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, and Harvard University to program several free, ancillary public events surrounding the performances such as lecture demonstrations and film screenings.

To support the Festival of Contemporary Music at Tanglewood Music Center. The festival, directed by composers John Harbison and Michael Gandolfi, will feature chamber music and orchestral performances by resident musicians and guest artists. Works by a wide array of contemporary composers will be highlighted including both established and emerging composers.

To support concerts of works by living composers with related educational activities. Plans include world premiere performances of Augusta Read Thomas's Cello Concerto No.3 with soloist Lynn Harrell and the symphony orchestra's first performances of two works by Oliver Knussen, Violin Concerto, Op. 30 and Whitman Settings for soprano and orchestra with the composer conducting.

To support the Festival of Contemporary Music at the Tanglewood Music Center. The five-day festival, directed by pianist Pierre-Laurent Aimard, will feature chamber music and orchestral performances by resident musicians and guest artists.

To support the Festival of Contemporary Music at the Tanglewood Music Center. The five-day festival, directed by composers John Harbison and Oliver Knussen, will feature chamber music and orchestral performances by resident musicians and guest artists.

To support performances of the world premiere of composer John Harbison's Symphony No. 6 and other new music performances with related educational activities. Works to be performed include the premiere of Harbison's new work conducted by David Zinman, Mark-Anthony Turnage's From the Wreckage (a trumpet concerto) conducted by Andris Nelsons, and Esa-Pekka Salonen's Violin Concerto conducted by the composer.

To support a new Friday evening subscription series featuring guest conductors with related educational activities. Conductors Sir Mark Elder, Susanna Malkki, and Thomas Ades will conduct Friday evening concerts in an informal format designed to attract a younger audience and will be broadcast on WGBH-FM radio.

To support the "Festival of Contemporary Music" at the Tanglewood Music Center. The multi-day festival, directed by composer Charles Wuorinen, will feature chamber music and orchestral performances by resident musicians and guest artists of works by contemporary composers including the premiere of a commissioned work by Wuorinen.

To support the Festival of Contemporary Music at the Tanglewood Music Center. The 70th anniversary festival will honor the resident composers who have led composition activities for the festival over the past seven decades.

To support premiere performances of new orchestral works and related educational activities. Three works by composers Elliott Carter, John Harbison, and Peter Lieberson will be premiered in three programs under the direction of Music Director James Levine.

To support the world premiere performances of a new work by composer Gunther Schuller. In celebration of the orchestra's 125th anniversary, four performances of the new work titled "Where the Word Ends" will take place including related educational activities.

To support the Festival of Contemporary Music at the Tanglewood Music Center. The multi-day concert series, under the direction of American composer Augusta Read Thomas, will feature significant modern works.

To support the Festival of Contemporary Music at the Tanglewood Music Center. The concert series, under the direction of Boston Symphony Orchestra's Music Director James Levine, will feature a centenary celebration of composer Elliott Carter.

To support world premiere performances of newly commissioned works by composers John Harbison and William Bolcom, with associated educational activities. As part of the orchestra's 125th anniversary season, the performances of the works will be preceded by lectures and an open rehearsal for local high school students.

To support the 2007 Festival of Contemporary Music at the Tanglewood Music Center. The concert series, directed by Pulitzer Prize-winning composer John Harbison, will feature performances of new music performed by pre-professional musicians and guest artists.
To support community concerts and online educational tools. Two online educational modules will be developed: one focusing on youth concerts and one on new commissions.

To support concerts and educational activities celebrating the works of Ludwig van Beethoven and Arnold Schoenberg. Plans include concerts, as well as expanded program notes, pre-concert lectures, a multi-media exhibit from the Arnold Schoenberg Center in Vienna, and scholarly symposia.

To support a concert opera performance of Richard Wagner's "The Flying Dutchman" and related activities. The three performances scheduled will be conducted by Music Director-designate James Levine during his debut season with the orchestra.

To support premiere performances of new works by American composers Milton Babbit, John Harbison, and Charles Wuorinen; and a performance of Elliott Carter's SYMPHONIA; as well as in-depth profiles of the composers on the symphony's website. The orchestra also will perform Elliott Carter's SYMPHONIA, a large-scale orchestral work augmented by a commissioned overture.
To support Days in the Arts at Tanglewood. The project will offer a summer arts immersion program including workshops and field trips for students from Berkshire County.

To support the Festival of Contemporary Music. The Tanglewood Music Center will present the week-long event within the summer 2003 Tanglewood Festival, featuring five to seven concerts by ensembles of Tanglewood fellows and guest artists.

To support the Festival of Contemporary Music. The Tanglewood Music Center will present the week long event within the summer Tanglewood Festival featuring five to seven concerts by ensembles of Tanglewood fellows and guest artists.

To support the Festival of Contemporary Music. In August 2001, Tanglewood Music Center (TMC) will present the week-long event within the Tanglewood Festival featuring five to seven concerts by ensembles of TMC fellows and guest artists and by the TMC Orchestra.
To support the Composer-in-Residence Program. Between five and eight composers will participate in rehearsals, dialogues with audiences, composition classes, and master classes.

To support the Festival of Contemporary Music at the Tanglewood Music Center. During August 2000, the week-long Festival will feature up to seven concerts of the Tanglewood Music Center Orchestra, and one concert of the Boston Symphony Orchestra as part of Tanglewood's 10-week summer festival.

To support the commission and presentation of a new musical work for children by Robert Xavier Rodriguez and the Underground Railway Theater. Teacher workshops and curriculum materials will be developed around this new work which is scheduled to be premiered in 2001.

To support a community performance initiative that will involve Boston Symphony Orchestra (BSO) musicians in the community through live orchestral and chamber concerts. Funds will be used for two free BSO youth concerts led by Music Director Seiji Ozawa in April 1999 and for a series of eight free chamber concerts by BSO player ensembles at various community sites in 1999-2000.

To support artist residencies at the Tanglewood Music Center. Leading soloists and conductors, music teachers, composers, and three selected chamber ensembles will participate in varying residencies, conducting master classes, workshops, and seminars.

To support a 1998 summer program of performance-oriented music professional training at the Tanglewood Music Center for instrumentalists, conductors, composers, and ensembles-in-residence selected by competitive auditions held in a number of American cities, with emphasis on reaching talented minority students, and a week-long contemporary music festival.

To support the centennial celebration of the opening of Symphony Hall with performances of eight retrospective works from the list of Boston Symphony Orchestra commissions and premieres and to commission and perform four new works.

Purpose: To support the Tanglewood Institute's Young Artists Orchestra and Young Artists Wind Ensemble. Additional Project Description: The Boston University Tanglewood Institute is an intensive, multi-week residential summer music program in Lenox, Massachusetts, for gifted high school musicians. The Young Artists Orchestra and the Young Artists Wind Ensemble students will study with professional musicians from distinguished orchestras such as the Boston Symphony Orchestra, perform community concerts, and attend Tanglewood Music Festival performances by established musicians. Online programming will be offered as necessary. Intended Beneficiaries: The program will benefit high school musicians from across the country. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries acquire knowledge and skills in the arts.

Purpose: To support the publication and promotion of the literary magazine AGNI. Additional Project Description: Committed to inspiring conversation and championing writers early in their careers, the journal features fiction, poetry, and nonfiction, with additional content, including reviews and interviews, offered through AGNI Online. Planned promotional activities include a newsletter and a digital marketing campaign. Intended Beneficiaries: The journal benefits readers nationwide. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support the BU Global Music Festival. Los Hermanos/The Brothers captures the parallel journeys of Ilmar and Aldo López-Gavilán, two brothers—one Cuban, the other Cuban-American—as they reunite for a cultural exchange program. Respected musicians in their home countries, the documentary follows their tour with the Harlem Quartet across the United States, playing music from both cultures. The film explores the brothers' past, recalling Ilmar's decision to leave Cuba to pursue a career in music, and Aldo's years at the London Conservatory before returning to Havana. Los Hermanos/The Brothers will be offered for public broadcast, and made available online, to public libraries, community groups, and as an educational resource to music programs.
