To support post-production costs for a documentary film by Elizabeth Harrington. The Center for Independent Documentary will produce "The Winding Stream", which tells the story of the Carters, the Cashes, and the efforts of the present day family to keep their legacy alive.

To support post-production of "Feelings Are Facts: The Life of Yvonne Rainer," a television documentary directed by Jack Walsh. Yvonne Rainer, the dancer, choreographer, performer, filmmaker and MacArthur Fellow, has been a key figure in the American avant-garde for five decades.

To support completion costs of a documentary film on Cinema Verite filmmaker Richard Leacock. A feature-length film by Jane Weiner, On Being There with Richard Leacock, will explore Leacock's 70-year career and his role in the evolution of observational documentary filmmaking.

To support the post-production costs of "Regarding Susan Sontag," a documentary by Nancy Kates. In the midst of her work as a critic, Sontag wrote 17 books, authored a play and several screenplays, and directed four films. She was referred to as "America's foremost female intellectual."

To support post-production and audience engagement costs for the documentary film "TRUST: Second Act in Young Lives." Stories to Tell follows the creation of a play at Chicago's Albany Park Theater Project.
To support production costs for a documentary, "Regarding Susan Sontag," by Nancy Kates. Regarding Susan Sontag will be a portrait of the late writer and critic (1933-2004).
To support the preservation of jobs that are threatened by declines in philanthropic and other support during the current economic downturn.
To support pre-production and production costs for a documentary, "Regarding Susan Sontag," a portrait of the late writer and critic by Nancy Kates.

To support completion costs for a documentary film on the American folk singer Woody Guthrie. Intended for national broadcast on PBS, the film will examine the life, work, and legacy of the man whose compositions include folk standards such as "This Land is Your Land" and "Roll on Columbia."
To support the production of a film on John James Audubon (1785-1851). Audubon: Drawn from Nature will be a one-hour documentary for PBS about the first great American painter of wildlife.

To support the production of a documentary on self-taught artists. The program will follow African American artists who make compositions out of bones, broken tools, fabric scraps, torn-up roots, rusty buckets, burned rope, car parts, and other "junk."

To support development of a Web site and related educational programming about Japanese vernacular architecture. Centered around the Kyo no Machiya, a 19th century silk merchant's home installed in the museum in the 1970s, the project will expand the audience via the Web with a three-dimensional immersive tour, archival film footage of its disassembly, crating, transport, and rebuilding in Boston, architectural and historic documents, a searchable catalogue of 1,000 artifacts associated with the house, and videos and curriculum about life in Kyoto today.

To support Head Start on KidStage, a consortium effort among The Children's Museum, City Stage Company, and Action for Boston Community Development, to provide theater arts education and access programs to Head Start teachers, children, and families, featuring performances and introductions to theater arts education The partners will offer workshops in theater arts to as many as 250 Head Start teachers and 12 education supervisors, introductions to theater arts for up to 2,100 Head Start children and families, and theater kits for Head Start centers. The Museum, an internationally recognized leader in the development and implementation of informal education for children, will host visits from all the Head Start students, with activities that will include KidStage performances and theater-related activities throughout the museum. ABCD is the primary provider of preschool and family intervention programs in Boston, with 27 sites and 119 classrooms throughout Boston. City Stage , founded in 1974, is known for pioneering techniques in theater for children and for creating innovative theatrical experiences in museum settings. Since 1988 City Stage has collaborated with the Museum on a variety of projects. City Stage and a group of teachers will produce production boxes and a curriculum guide for use by teachers in future years. Learnings from the project will be disseminated nationwide through various channels.

Purpose: To support a performance of David Lang's The Little Match Girl Passion. Additional Project Description: The 2008 Pulitzer Prize-winning work based on the 1845 Hans Christian Andersen story will take place at Church of the Covenant. Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed project will serve audiences in the Boston metropolitan area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support community engagement, cultural asset mapping, and arts programming for the Little Saigon Cultural District in Boston, in partnership with the Networking Organization for Vietnamese Americans. Project activities will include public programming such as murals, festivals, and performances to celebrate the rich and vibrant Vietnamese culture of the Dorchester neighborhood. The Mayor's Office of Arts and Culture and the Networking Organization for Vietnamese Americans will lead the project with long-term goals of instilling a sense of community heritage and pride, empowering residents to combat displacement, increasing employment opportunities, and supporting local business development.

To support the Mayor's Office of Arts and Culture's Project Partnership grant program, offering grant funds and technical assistance for community arts and cultural events and projects. Through this pilot initiative, the city will of support projects for historically underserved artists and communities throughout Boston.

Discipline / Field: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act
Category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act
Project Description: To support administration costs and related subgranting to the nonprofit arts sector in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

To support arts programming and cultural district planning in Boston's Latin Quarter. Project activities include performing arts events and cultural activities led by artists in residence and the creation of a long-term cultural district plan crafted by the Metropolitan Area Planning Council. The project also includes a branding and marketing plan for the Latin Quarter. The project is a partnership between the Mayor's Office of Arts and Culture and the Hyde Square Task Force. Boston's Latin Quarter is a community in transition, with a long history of residents with Latin American roots, many of whom are low-income.

To support the Emerge Boston Arts program. A series of performing arts presentations and visual arts showcases will be featured throughout Boston City Hall. The city will issue an open call for artist participation, to be juried by a panel of professional artists and curators prior to selection. The series will explore the civic role of art and design by establishing City Hall as a place that actively fosters cultural events and community dialogue.

To support an artist residency program in Boston City Hall. Artists will be selected to work alongside city departments and introduce creative approaches that transform the delivery of municipal services. The residency program will provide participating artists with stipends, capacity development, training, and support to execute a pilot project. The City of Boston will partner with Massachusetts College of Art and Design to embed artists in local government work and bring new ideas for implementing Boston's Mobility Action Plan and 100 Resilient Cities Plan.
To support a folk arts director's position and other related costs. The folk arts director will identify, research, and make accessible the authentic art forms and traditoins of Boston.

To support the Stage Door Apprentice Touring Troupe. The program helps young actors transition between high school and college level theater training by building their resumes and helping develop writing and acting skills.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support artist residencies in the theater arts. Professional artists will work at one elementary school and one high school to lead students in the rehearsal and performance of classic works of literature.

To support completion costs for a nationally broadcast public television series that will examine the contributions of African-American artists in the 20th Century. "I'll Make Me a World" will examine the unique contributions of African- American music, literature, visual arts, theater, and dance to 20th century American history and culture. Through its prime-time broadcast over three nights in the fall/winter of 1998 and through formal and informal educational use, the series will reach millions of people. African-American artists have been the unrecognized authors of so much of what is considered American culture. The innovations of black music infuses all American forms from folk to orchestra, from opera to the top forty. Black dance has given shape to much of American popular dance, from its beginnings in open air dances o n plantations and in towns throughout the South, to the African origins of the Cakewalk, the Black Bottom, and the Lindy Hop. African- American artists have performed on our theatrical stages since the end of slavery, and are today in an unprecedented period of achievement as writers, actors, directors and producers of American theater and film. Visual artists and writers have provided models for other emerging cultures of identity. Executive Producer: H

Purpose: To support the annual Free Shakespeare on the Common program, featuring a production of "Macbeth" by William Shakespeare. Additional Project Description: The free, outdoor performances will be accompanied by community engagement activities such as backstage tours and workshops for audience members. Early-career actors from the theater's training programs will be cast in the production. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit theater artists and audiences in Greater Boston. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support the annual Free Shakespeare on the Common program, featuring a production of Much Ado About Nothing by William Shakespeare. Additional Project Description: The free, outdoor performances will be accompanied by community engagement activities such as backstage tours and workshops for audience members. Early career actors from the theater's training programs will be cast in the production. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit theater artists and audiences in Greater Boston, Massachusetts. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support staff salaries for planning the annual Free Shakespeare on the Common program, featuring a production of The Tempest by William Shakespeare. The free, outdoor performances will be accompanied by community engagement activities such as backstage tours and workshops for audience members. Early career actors from the theater's training programs will be cast in the production.

To support a production of "Richard III" in Free Shakespeare on the Common. Audiences will experience a contemporary professional production in one of the nation's oldest public parks that is centrally located, accessible, and close to public transportation. The company will illustrate the relevance of Shakespeare's ideas and the beauty of his language, and will break down the barriers that keep people from experiencing live theater.

To support Free Shakespeare on the Common. Audiences will experience a contemporary professional production of William Shakespeare's "Romeo and Juliet." An open-air theater set will be built in one of the nation's oldest public parks that is centrally located, accessible, and close to public transportation. The company will illustrate the relevance of Shakespeare's ideas and the beauty of his language, and will break down the barriers that keep people from experiencing live theater. The Boston tradition of offering free Shakespeare is in its 21st year and is supported by both civic leaders and the public.

To support Free Shakespeare on the Common. Audiences will experience a contemporary professional production of William Shakespeare's "Love's Labour's Lost." The company will build an open-air theater set in one of the nation's oldest public parks that is centrally located, accessible, and close to public transportation. The company will illustrate the relevance of Shakespeare's ideas and the beauty of his language, and will break down the barriers that keep people from experiencing live theater. The Boston tradition of offering free Shakespeare is supported by both civic leaders and the public.

To support Shakespeare OFF the Common, a program that includes theater workshops in Boston Public Schools and free performances in neighborhood parks. Workshops and performances will engage students, local artists, and community groups to participate in performances and to expose new audiences to the work of Shakespeare. Partners include the City of Boston's Mayor's Office of Arts, Tourism  Special Events and the Boys and Girls Club of Boston. Workshops and performances will target underserved youth and residents in the Dorchester, Roxbury, and Mattapan neighborhoods.

Organization Name: Community Music Center of Boston, Inc.
Project Description: Purpose: To support a professional development project for teachers. Additional Project Description: Faculty and staff will participate in monthly workshops using a trauma-sensitive, culturally inclusive music curriculum designed to enhance their teaching skills to meet the diverse needs of students. Participating youth will receive stipends to assist with curricular design and assessment. External evaluators will refine the curriculum and assessment tools which will be shared with the public. Intended Beneficiaries: Arts educators throughout Boston will benefit from the project. Intended Outcomes: Beneficiaries acquire knowledge and skills in the arts.

Organization Name: Community Music Center of Boston, Inc.
Project Description: Purpose: To support an artist workforce development program focused on early-career artists in Boston. Additional Project Description: As many as 30 early-career artists will receive paid arts sector workforce training, paid externships at arts agencies with mentorship, and stipends to produce arts projects across the city. The project will be a partnership with the City of Boston and local arts and culture organizations, including Abilities Dance, Boston Chinatown Neighborhood Center, Castle of our Skins, Dunamis, the Center for Teen Empowerment, and the Record Co. The project will model new approaches for supporting early-career artists—with a focus on artists of color—preparing them to enter the arts and culture sector, while also reconsidering the ways in which the community supports arts infrastructure. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit early-career artists who will participate in the program. The culminating events will serve Boston-area residents. Intended Outcome: The arts are integrated into the fabric of community life.

Organization Name: Community Music Center of Boston, Inc.
Project Description: To support a music education program in partnership with public schools in Boston. Teaching artists will provide instruction to students through classes such as African drumming, orchestral strings, general music, and musical theater. Other program activities will include programmatic support for school administrators and opportunities for the students to perform in year-end showcases and community events.

Purpose: To support the production of Can I Touch It? by Francisca Da Silveira, directed by Summer L. Williams. Additional Project Description: The play examines themes of Black hair politics, social exclusion, gentrification, and the struggles Black-owned small business owners face. Community engagement activities will include the Young Producers program for high school students, a workforce development program conducted in partnership with Boston's Department of Youth Employment and Engagement, Action for Boston Community Development, and the Madison Park Development Corporation. Intended Beneficiaries: The program will benefit theater artists, audiences, and youth in Boston. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation's cultural infrastructure.
To support general operating costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

To support the production of Leftovers by Josh Wilder. When an enormous dandelion sprouts in front of their South Philly home and wishes start falling from the sky, two brothers begin to dream their way out of the cycle of poverty that has governed their lives and find themselves on an adventure they never could have imagined. The world premiere production will take place at Boston's Strand Theatre.

To support a series of performances and community outreach activities that will explore the impact of Bill T. Jones' work on the contemporary dance and visual arts communities. The Bill T. Jones Legacy Project will feature performances by the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company, as well as the company's former dancers S an Curran, Heidi Latsky, and Larry Goldhuber.
To support the creation and presentation of contemporary dance works. Companies in the series include Pilobolus Dance Theatre, Bill T. Jones, Hubbard Street Dance Chicago, and Urban Bush Women.

To support the research, development, and implementation of a new International Festival of Aerial Dance. The festival will showcase eight to ten works by both seasoned aerial dancers and by leading artists who are beginning to explore movement possibilities of working off the ground.

To support a consortium project for Minds in Motion 2000, a comprehensive dance education program. Minds in Motion 2000, a project with Boston Public Schools, will provide both disciplined-based dance education and curriculum-based teacher training, as well as performances and residency activities, including master classes, lecture- demonstrations, and "Meet the Artists" sessions.

To support artistic residencies and the creation and presentation of new works by and for AXIS Dance Troupe in collaboration with choreographer Bill T. Jones and interdisciplinary artist William Shannon. The centerpiece of this project will be the creation and presentation of two new works for AXIS Dance Troupe, a leading mixed-ability company from Oakland, California using dancers with and without physical disabilities. The first piece will be created by AXIS company members and the second by choreographer Bill T. Jones. In addition, this project will commission and provide residency support for disabled artist William Shannon. As part of Mr. Shannon's research and residency, he will design and fabricate a technologically advanced crutch that is necessary for the creation of his new interdisciplinary dance theater piece. The residency will also provide Mr. Shannon with an opportunity for technical and artistic exchange with AXIS Dance Troupe and the national dance and disability community.

To support the Forum on Design Management Research and Education. Project plans include broadening participation and diversity in the biennial conference of researchers, educators, students, and practitioners, by subsidizing entry fees.

Purpose: To support the Boston Public Schools Arts Expansion, an ongoing collective impact initiative. Additional Project Description: Building on the Boston Public Schools' strategic plan, project activities will include data collection and analysis to uncover inequities in access to arts education for students. Arts education data will be disseminated to the community and to policy makers, and students will receive in-school arts instruction. Professional development for teachers and partner organization convenings will focus on racial justice, the effects of remote learning, and trauma-informed arts instruction. Intended Beneficiaries: The initiative will benefit students, many of whom come from low-income communities, educators, schools, and arts organizations in Boston, Massachusetts. Intended Outcomes: Beneficiaries acquire knowledge and skills in the arts.

To support the Boston Public Schools Arts Expansion, an ongoing collective impact effort serving students across Boston Public Schools. EdVestors will work to increase the frequency and quality of arts instruction in Boston. Project activities will include meetings and convenings, professional development for teachers, and data collection and analysis to support the implementation of the School Arts Index, which provides data to track arts instruction across BPS.

Purpose: To support payments to writers, editorial salary costs, and the printing of the journal Ploughshares. Additional Project Description: Featuring poetry, fiction, and nonfiction, including long-form stories and essays, the quarterly journal showcases both emerging and established writers. Each year, two issues of Ploughshares are curated by guest editors who bring their unique editorial visions to the publication. Planned guest editors include Jamel Brinkley and Ilya Kaminsky. Intended Beneficiaries: The journal will benefit readers nationwide. Intended Outcomes: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

Purpose: To support the development and presentation of multidisciplinary works at ArtsEmerson, and related activities. Additional Project Description: Featured new works will reclaim and reexamine history and historical turning points in Black and Asian American experiences, and may include Daniel "KOA" Beaty's solo play The Garden and Eugenie Chan's vaudeville performance The Truer Story of the Chan Family. Associated community engagement programs also will be offered. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit featured artists, ArtsEmerson's Greater Boston audience, and its growing global community. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation's cultural infrastructure.

Purpose: To support a convening about international presenting produced by HowlRound. Additional Project Description: U.S.-based presenters of international work, artists, funders, and other key stakeholders will gather in NYC to advance and deepen knowledge, commitments, and practices of international cultural exchange in the age of COVID-19 and the climate emergency. Produced in partnership with the International Presenting Commons, the convening will be livestreamed on HowlRound TV and documented via the HowlRound journal. Intended Beneficiaries: The convening will benefit invited participants, HowlRound's international audience via HowlRound TV, and the international presenting field at large. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation's cultural infrastructure.

To support payments to writers, editorial salary costs, and the printing of the journal Ploughshares. Featuring poetry, fiction, and nonfiction, including longform stories and essays, the quarterly journal showcases both emerging and established writers. Each year, two issues of Ploughshares are curated by guest editors who bring their unique editorial visions to the publication. Planned guest editors include Aimee Bender and Laura van den Berg.

To support the Latinx Theatre Commons' Colaboratorio Director  Designer Process Lab Hosted by HowlRound Theatre Commons. The convening will feature a series of workshops, play viewings, venue tours, and programming to investigate innovative approaches to rehearsal processes for theater directors and designers. Participating artists will build new methods for collaborative theater making through sharing their experiences and expertise.
To support general operating costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

To support payments to writers, editorial salary costs, and the printing of the journal Ploughshares. Featuring poetry, fiction, and nonfiction, including longform stories and essays, the quarterly journal showcases both emerging and established writers. Each year, two issues of Ploughshares are curated by guest editors who bring their unique editorial visions to the publication; planned guest editors include Celeste Ng and Tracy K. Smith. This award will support the Spring 2020, Summer 2020 and Fall 2020 issues.

To support HowlRound Theatre Commons' Latinx Theatre Commons Comedy Carnaval convening. Theater practitioners will gather in Denver to explore a broad range of theatrical comedy content and share best practices in artistic programming. Convening activities will include a full production of a comedic play, new play readings, stand-up, sketch, improvisation workshops, live podcast recordings, and discussions focused on Latinx comedy in the Americas.

To support development of a new jazz opera by Esperanza Spaulding and NEA Jazz Master Wayne Shorter at ArtsEmerson. Jazz artist Esperanza Spalding will develop a new jazz opera, Iphigenia, with NEA Jazz Master Wayne Shorter composing the score and architect Frank Gehry designing the set. ArtsEmerson will work with artists and partner organizations to provide engagement and educational activities.

To support costs associated with the creation and publication of the journal Ploughshares. Publishing poetry, fiction, and nonfiction, including longform stories and essays, the quarterly journal showcases both emerging and established writers. Each year, two issues of Ploughshares are curated by guest editors who bring their varied and unique editorial visions to the publication. Planned guest editors include Rigoberto González and Viet Thanh Nguyen.

To support the commissioning, development, and presentation of multidisciplinary works at ArtsEmerson. ArtsEmerson will work with artists and partner organizations to provide engagement and educational activities.

To support the development of an online World Theatre Map as part of HowlRound. The World Theatre Map will be a user-generated directory and real time map of the global theater community, providing a collectively owned, people-powered infrastructure to connect isolated theater makers to information, resources, and knowledge. HowlRound is a set of free, shared communication platforms for the theater community that includes the World Theatre Map, an online journal, and a livestreaming television network designed to enable theater artists, practitioners, and organizations to engage in fieldwide learning and knowledge sharing.

To support artist fees and related costs for a series of international multidisciplinary performances at ArtsEmerson. The performances will include presentations by circus company Global Arts Corps (Cambodia) and multidisciplinary artist Marc Bamuthi Joseph. ArtsEmerson will work with artists and partner organizations to provide engagement and educational activities.

To support the publication and promotion of "Ploughshares Solos." Serially published single stories and essays are produced and distributed electronically and subsequently collected in "Omnibus," an annual print volume. Suited for longer-form writing, which seldom receives publication in traditional print journals, the work will be promoted through the publication's blog, e-newsletter, social media, and other platforms.

To support HowlRound, a knowledge commons by and for the theatre community. Through a set of communication platforms dedicated to revitalizing the American theater, the project will explore the challenges of a live art form in a digital age. Platforms will include the HowlRound Journal; HowlRound TV, an online platform featuring live streaming and a video archive of performances, conversations, and conferences; and HowlRound Convenings, all of which will help artists to join in a national conversation, and technical support for the World Theatre Map, an interactive real time map of theater happening all over the world. HowlRound's open source online platform will enable theater artists, practitioners, and organizations to engage in fieldwide learning and knowledge sharing.

To support ArtsEmerson's World On Stage series. The international, multidisciplinary series will be part of ArtsEmerson's 2017-18 season, featuring culturally diverse works by master artists from the United States, Belgium, and Cambodia. The series will feature a variety of artist residencies, world premieres, presentations, and dialogue to engage an audience drawn from communities in the Boston area.

To support the publication and promotion of "Ploughshares Solos." Serially published single stories and essays are produced and distributed electronically and subsequently collected in an annual print volume. Suited for novellas and long essays, which seldom receive publication in traditional print journals, the work will be promoted through the blog, newsletter, social media, and other platforms.

HowlRound's open source online platform will enable theater artists, practitioners, and organizations to engage in fieldwide learning and knowledge sharing.

To support a series of multidisciplinary programming in Boston's Chinatown neighborhood. In addition to opera and film events, engagement activities will include "Welcome to Boston" exchanges where artists will be introduced to local residents. The project will also include a presentation of the Chinese Exclusion Staged Reading directed by Susan Chinsen. Emerson College is located in Boston's Chinatown neighborhood.

To support the publication and promotion of "Ploughshares Solos." Serially published stories and essays will be produced electronically and subsequently collected in an annual print volume. Suited for novellas and long essays, which seldom receive publication in traditional print journals, the solos will also be made available in audio format through Audible.

To support the development and presentation of multidisciplinary, contemporary performances and related activities at ArtsEmerson. Performances will include Robert LePage's "Needles and Opium," mixing jazz with a multimedia aesthetic of props, projections, and other technical components, as well as poet/performer/playwright Daniel Beaty's "Breath and Imagination," a text-based play with music.

To support HowlRound: A Center for Theater Commons. Through a set of communication platforms dedicated to revitalizing the American theater, the project will explore the challenges of a live art form in a digital age. Platforms will include the HowlRound Journal; HowlRound TV, an online platform featuring live streaming and a video archive of performances, conversations, and conferences; and HowlRound Convenings, all of which will empower artists to join in a national conversation. Free access to HowlRound's open source online platform will enable theater artists, practitioners, and organizations to engage in fieldwide learning and knowledge sharing.
To support the publication of "Ploughshares Solos Omnibus." "Solos" are long-form, serially published stories and essays produced electronically, then collected in an annual print volume.

To support ArtsEmerson: The World On Stage Theater Development Residencies. The project will foster the creation of new work by offering residencies, rehearsal space, production facilities and support, and performance space on the campus of Emerson College in Boston.

To support the publication and promotion of the guest-edited journal "Ploughshares," as well as the digital publication of 40 years of back issues. The editorial policy of Ploughshares stipulates that each issue be guest-edited by a writer who is given autonomy to apply his or her aesthetic vision; planned guest editors include Major Jackson and Peter Ho Davies.

To support the publication and national distribution of the literary journal "Ploughshares." The editorial policy of "Ploughshares" stipulates that each issue be guest-edited by a writer who is given autonomy to apply his or her aesthetic vision; planned guest editors include Nick Flynn and Patricia Hampl.

To support ArtsEmerson: The World On Stage to foster the creation of new work by offering residencies, rehearsal space, production facilities and support, and performance space on the campus of Emerson College in Boston. ArtsEmerson intends to work with the following ensembles: The Civilians, The Foundry Theatre, Elevator Repair Service, Theatre of the Emerging American Movement, and Phantom Limb Company.

To support the publication and national distribution of PLOUGHSHARES. The editorial policy of Ploughshares stipulates that each issue be guest-edited by a writer who is given editorial autonomy to apply his or her aesthetic vision.

To support the publication and national distribution of issues of PLOUGHSHARES. The Fall 2009, Winter 2009-10, and Spring 2010 issues will feature new work by as many as 35 poets and 20 fiction writers.
To support the publication and national distribution of issues of PLOUGHSHARES.

To support presentations of the works of composers Joseph Haydn and Arnold Schoenberg with related educational activities. Solo piano and orchestral music will be presented highlighting the two Viennese composers.
To support the preservation of jobs that are threatened by declines in philanthropic and other support during the current economic downturn.

To support artists' fees for performances of Bach's "St. Matthew's Passion" and related educational activities. The performances will be a tribute to the memory of founding music director Craig Smith.
To support a festival of George Frederic Handel's operas performed in concert format. The trilogy of operas will include Orlando, Ariodante, and Alcina.

To support a retrospective of concerts and lectures on the chamber music of John Harbison. A series of eight concerts to take place at Emmanuel Church and MIT's Killan Hall, will examine the composer's works and influences on his music and will include four Boston premiers and two world premiers.

To support a planning project. During 1999-2000, Emmanuel Music requires technical assistance to develop and write a three-year plan for stabilizing its organization, with an emphasis on staff and board development.

To support Opening Our Doors Artists Residency salons. Youth and seniors will participate in workshops with artists in a variety of disciplines including storytelling, visual arts, and architecture. Intergenerational participants also will be paired to work collaboratively on short-term interdisciplinary art projects during salon sessions. The project will culminate in an exhibition as part of the Opening Our Doors festival.

To support preservation, interpretation, and documentation of 19th-century sculpture and stone carving at Forest Hills Cemetery. The nationally significant outdoor collection located at a 250-acre Victorian cemetery, which is on the National Register of Historic Places, is at urgent risk due to damage from weather and pollution.

To support an exhibition of site-specific sculptures. Participating artists will be provided with an stipend and the technical assistance required to produce temporary works to be installed on the grounds of an historic cemetery.

Organization Name: Friends of Jewish Community Housing for the Elderly Inc.
Project Description: To support a multidisciplinary arts program focusing on older adults. Adults residing in Jewish Community Housing for the Elderly's (JCHE) affordable, non-denominational assisted living facilities will be offered creative arts opportunities that promote healthy aging. Professional teaching artists will offer sessions in art-making, drama, dance and creative movement, and storytelling. Participants will have opportunities to share their creative talents and projects with their families and the greater community. JCHE will partner with Lesley University's Institute for Arts and Health to develop training and replication components in order to further disseminate the program model.

Organization Name: Friends of Jewish Community Housing for the Elderly Inc.
Project Description: To support the Multi-Media Arts Project. Adults residing in Jewish Community Housing for the Elderly's affordable, non-denominational assisted living will be offered creative arts opportunities that promote healthy aging. Sessions will include interactive visual arts and music workshops, mural making, drama, dance, and storytelling. Participants will have opportunities to share their creative talents and projects with their families and the greater community.

Organization Name: Friends of the East Boston Branch Boston Public Library,Inc.
Project Description: To support continued restoration efforts for the painting series "Ships Through the Ages," by Frederick Leonard King (1879-1947). A product of the Federal Art Project, the series of paintings are located at the East Boston Branch of the Boston Public Library.

Purpose: To support the online Learning and Media Lab for pre-professional musicians. Additional Project Description: The young musicians who appear on the classical radio program "From the Top" will take part in the Learning and Media Lab, a series of virtual workshops and educational sessions around leadership, community, and the role of musicians in today's world. The musicians will use this training to plan and execute a virtual community engagement activity. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit the musicians selected by audition to participate as well as the communities across the country where the engagement activities take place. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation's cultural infrastructure.

To support educational outreach activities. Select youth musicians who appear on the classical radio program From the Top will take part in a series of leadership trainings and community engagement residencies. The young musicians will perform in school classrooms and community venues, and will participate in workshops that will help them connect with audiences and become peer role models. Activities may take place virtually.
To support the production of the public radio broadcast series From the Top. The weekly program features performances by young classical musicians recorded at live events across the country.

To support educational outreach activities. Select youth musicians who appear on the classical radio program From the Top will take part in the Arts Leadership Summit series, a set of education and community engagement residencies. The young musicians will perform for school students and community members, and will participate in workshops that will help them connect with audiences and become peer role models. These activities are expected to be conducted virtually.

To support educational outreach activities. Selected youth musicians ages 8 to 18 who appear on the classical radio program From the Top will take part in the Center for the Development of Arts Leaders (CDAL) arts leadership and outreach program. The young musicians will perform concerts in school classrooms and community venues, and will participate in workshops that will help them connect with audiences and become positive peer role models.

To support the production of the public radio broadcast series From the Top. The weekly program features performances by young classical musicians recorded at live events in towns and cities across the country.

To support educational outreach activities. Selected musicians, aged 8 to 18, who appear on the classical radio program From the Top will take part in the Center for the Development of Arts Leaders, an arts leadership and outreach program. The workshops will help prepare young musicians to connect with new audiences and to serve as positive peer role models. In this comedy, three sisters and their mother grapple with their individual and collective notions of home and identity during a family reunion. Talkbacks and other audience engagement activities will focus on the themes of the play, including the economic, historical, and sociological factors that shape African-American women's relationships to identity, family, and success.

To support a production of Indecent by Paula Vogel. The play follows the story of the 1906 play God of Vengeance by Sholem Asch, and how it changed the lives of all who encountered it. The controversial God of Vengeance broke boundaries in its complex and compassionate depictions of family, faith, and sexuality. The play toured the Yiddish and mainstream theater circuits in Europe before coming to the United States and then to Broadway in 1923, where it was shut down for public indecency. Co-produced with Center Theatre Group in Los Angeles, the production will re-create the Broadway staging by Tony Award-winning director Rebecca Taichman.

To support the production of "Top Girls" by Caryl Churchill. Written during the Thatcher era, Churchill portrays a societal ambivalence toward women's ambition and success. The play opens with a gathering of boundary-breaking women from history and then moves to the early 1980s Britain to examine what it means for women to be workers, mothers, wives, daughters, and sisters.

To support the production of "The Who and The What" by Ayad Akhtar. The play follows a young Muslim-American woman who is writing a book about the role of women in Islam. The story unfolds as a multidimensional discussion of Islamic identity, how our relationship to faith changes through time, and a deconstruction of patriarchal assumptions in both American and Islamic cultures. Project activities will involve engaging Greater Boston audiences in discussions about the complexities of Muslim-American identity through the performances as well as a series of talkbacks and public events.

To support the premiere of "I Was Most Alive with You" by Craig Lucas. The play explores questions of faith and struggles with addiction through its portrayal of a contemporary and diverse group of family and friends who are described as atheist, Jewish, Buddhist, gay, straight, Deaf and hearing, African American, and Iranian. Two of the characters are Deaf and will be played by Deaf actors. Lucas will direct the production, and his intent is for Deaf and hearing audience members to have as close to simultaneous and equivalent experiences as possible. Actors will use sign language, sign language interpreters will be onstage and a part of the action of the play, and projections of the dialogue will occur when sign language is used without speech, or speech without sign language.

Her work encompasses ceramic sculpture, metals, performance, installation, writing, and automobile design, exploring themes of gender, race, and identity, building awareness around Indigenous culture, and place. From small-scale works to large-scale standing figures, pieces in the exhibition will reveal the techniques and themes that define Simpson's artistic practice. Intended Beneficiaries: The exhibition will reach general audiences, with a focus on the Boston-area academic community. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

Popular Name: aka The Institute of Contemporary Art/Boston
Project Description: To support the exhibition Tschabalala Self: Out of Body and related programming. Boston visitors, residents, and students will be introduced to Tschabalala Self (b. 1990), an emerging artist whose work traverses diverse artistic and craft traditions and engages in dialogue about urban environments, the body, and Black femininity. Self's figurative painting practice incorporates eclectic materials and techniques like hand-printed and found textiles, stitching, paper, and painted fabric.

Popular Name: aka The Institute of Contemporary Art/Boston
Project Description: To support the exhibition Huma Bhabha: They Live. The exhibition will be the first comprehensive museum exhibition of American/Pakistani artist Huma Bhabha (b. 1962), highlighting her prolific output from the last two decades in sculpture, drawing, and photography. More than 50 of the artists' works will be featured that demonstrate her distinctive visual vocabulary, which draws upon a variety of influences, from horror films and science fiction, to ancient artifacts, religious reliquary, modernist sculpture, and German Expressionism. The exhibition will explore Bhabha's engagement with the human figure and her capacity to rework familiar everyday objects into sculptures. An array of programs will complement the exhibition such as: tours, public talks, and teen programs, which are intended to provide multiple entry points into the artist's oeuvre.

Popular Name: aka The Institute of Contemporary Art/Boston
Project Description: To support a free visual arts learning program for teens. The WallTalk program enables Boston-area students to work with professional artists to develop skills of self-expression through visual art making, creative writing, and spoken-word activities that connect with the classroom curriculum and exhibitions at the Institute of Contemporary Art, Boston. Students also will create original visual art and spoken-word works and share their pieces with peers and in public presentations.

Popular Name: aka The Institute of Contemporary Art/Boston
Project Description: To support an exhibition, catalogue and related programming examining art in the age of the Internet. The exhibition, "Art in the Age of the Internet, 1989 to Today," examines how the Internet has radically changed the field of art and explores themes such as the circulation and control of images and information; surveillance and resistance; the explosion of new communities and virtual worlds; and new economies of visibility initiated by social media through the presentation of work in a variety of mediums. Works by more than 50 artists will be presented in the exhibition of painting, performance, photography, sculpture, video, and websites-that all investigate the extensive effects of the Internet on artistic practice and the broader culture and the democratization of culture in the current moment. An illustrated scholarly publication and extensive web platform will give access to the research process and capture ongoing dialogues; tours, public talks, and teen programs will engage audiences.

Popular Name: aka The Institute of Contemporary Art/Boston
Project Description: To support the project "First Light: A Decade of Collecting at the ICA," and related programming. Celebrating its tenth anniversary on the Boston waterfront, the ICA plans an ambitious series of rotating installations using the recent gift of the Barbara Lee Collection of Art by Women as the foundation for the project's art historical and thematic groupings. This collection of 43 major works covers a range of material and conceptual approaches. Works on loan from other institutions also will be included by artists such as Rachel Harrison, Glenn Ligon, Kerry James Marshall, Nick Cave, Sophie Calle, Kiki Smith, Lorna Simpson, and Peter Hujar, Paul Chan, Ellen Gallagher, and Kara Walker. Public talks, tours, teen programs and the creation of a microsite with robust content will complement the exhibition of art work.

Students will create their own original visual art and spoken-word works, and learn to share their work with their peers and in public presentations.

Featuring works of art by American and international artists, ranging from small-scale, intricate weavings to large walk-in environments, the exhibition will explore abstraction in fiber from the mid-20th century to the present.

Students will develop skills of self-expression through visual art making, creative writing, and spoken-word activities that connect with the classroom curriculum and exhibitions at the Institute of Contemporary Arts Boston.

The artist's work has centered on a life-long investigation of the relationship between art, politics, trauma, and healing.

Project Description: To support a consortium Artist-in-Residence program. Working with Boston's National Historical Park and the Boston Arts Academy (BAA), the Institute of Contemporary Art (ICA)will partner students and artists to create temporary public artworks.

Project Description: To support the exhibition "Sites Unseen-Shimon Attie: Photographs and Public Projects, 1992-1998," with an accompanying catalogue and video. This traveling exhibition will be the first in-depth exhibition of the artist's work.

Additional Project Description: Artists will create work and develop programs and workshops in response to the museum's collection and exhibitions. These projects will engage young, local, and more diverse audiences with a variety of experiences, exploring areas such as botany (in response to the museum's garden), poetry, and comic books and graphic art. The projects are a part of ongoing work by the museum to be a source of inspiration and a cultural home for its artist partners and community. The museum also will commission two public art works for its exterior façade and will host a series of programs featuring storytelling, performances, films, and interactive gallery experiences.

To support an artist residency and exhibition program. The program is designed to allow contemporary artists an opportunity to draw upon the museum's world-renowned historical collection for inspiration and to participate in the Museum's School and Community Partnership outreach programs.

To support the conservation of four 16th- and 17th-century Flemish masterpiece tapestries at the Textile Conservation Center in Lowell, MA, in anticipation of their reinstallation in climate-controlled public spaces in the museum. The project will be undertaken at the Textile Conservation Center in Lowell, MA, a regional conservation center with a longstanding reputation for excellence in textile conservation. The project has been timed so that the tapestries will be reinstalled in their permanent spaces after completion of museum-wide climate control. By that time, in the year 2000, the museum expects annual attendance to reach 200,000. For a museum of its size, the Gardner is the repository of one of the finest collections of historic tapestries in the United States and has undertaken a long- range plan to conserve those in most urgent need of repair. Each tapestry was personally selected by Ms. Gardner and as works of monumental proportions, all of them have a major impact on the appearance and ambiance of the galleries and the visitor experience.

To support educational composition workshops and performances. Students will take part in workshops in collaboration with teaching artists and guest artists culminating in performances of student compositions. Project activities may take place in-person or online as necessary.

Purpose: To support a mural arts project and arts programming in state correctional facilities. Additional Project Description: In partnership with Freedom Reads, a nonprofit organization that provides literature to people in prison, MASS Design Group will work with regional artists and incarcerated individuals at as many as three state correctional facilities across the United States to design and install painted murals. Participants will develop a design concept, paint murals, and coordinate with superintendents to ensure compliance with facility regulations. A series of events also will be presented at correctional facilities, including conversations with artists. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will engage incarcerated individuals in mural design and creation. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries experience advances in their health and well-being.
To support general operating costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

To support the publication Fringe City Futures, which explores the way that small industrial cities are being reinvented in the wake of deindustrialization and demographic change. The book is being produced in tandem with an exhibition curated by MASS Design Group in partnership with the American Institute of Architects New York. The publication will reach design networks across the country with the ultimate goal of introducing new design solutions to drive urban revitalization efforts.

To support community design workshops and an exhibition focused on Fall Kill Creek in Poughkeepsie, New York. Three-dimensional digital and physical models and a photography exhibition will reveal the physical and seasonal aspects of this marginalized urban creek. Placemaking workshops and site-specific temporary installations on Main Street and Pershing Avenue will draw residents together and explore ways in which the creek can help make their neighborhoods more ecologically resilient and socially cohesive. The design studies are intended to inspire new landscape ideas, encourage environmental stewardship, and activate the creek as a community asset.

To support community design workshops and architectural designs for the adaptive reuse of the planned decommissioning of an underground cistern into a community cultural facility in Poughkeepsie, New York in partnership with the City of Poughkeepsie, New York. The project will serve as a space for cultural amenities and become a national model for how decommissioned infrastructure can provide opportunities for civic engagement.

To support design fellows salaries for the Hudson Valley Design Center. Working with residents, local organizations and regional institutions, MASS Design Group will open a design center in Poughkeepsie, New York. As a post-industrial, rust belt city, Poughkeepsie has suffered from decades of economic neglect and has had difficulty reinventing itself. The fellows will support the new design center, utilizing physical and community infrastructure that engages residents in developing a vibrant vision of a growing local economy and rebranding Poughkeepsie as an inviting city for business innovation.

To support a conservation survey of artworks in the Boston area subway system's public art collection. The project will include studies of a neon sculpture by Alejandro and Moira Sina and a tile wall by Joyce Kozloff.

Students also will have the option to participate in an elective studio from the following areas: painting from observation, graphic design, fashion design, photography, jewelry and metalsmithing, and illustration. Students will develop critical thinking skills through the study of art history and gallery visits.

Project Description: To support a major public exhibition of video art made in the United States during the last three decades, which will include an accompanying catalogue. The exhibition and catalog will present a comprehensive history of experimental video art to the public and will critically examine the influence of early works and technologies on contemporary video art. Approximately 75 video art works created between 1968-1998 by over 50 artists from across the United States will be shown. The core of this historical exhibition will be drawn from the archives of the New Television Workshop at WGBH-TV, which was established in 1974 to provide artists from various disciplines the tools necessary to create pioneering works. Some of the artists to be included are: Trisha Brown, Nam June Paik, Meredith Monk, Charles Atlas, Peter Campus, Gus Solomons, Tony Oursler, etc. In addition, examples of early video cameras, modified television monitors and editing systems, along with more special effects hardware, will be incorporated into the exhibition design, giving the viewer a sense of the challenges posed by early technology, and of the changing processes involved in the creation of video art.

Purpose: To support an exhibition featuring work by enslaved potters of the 19th-century South. Additional Project Description: Curated in partnership with the Metropolitan Museum of Art and a diverse advisory team of artists and historians, the exhibition will be a landmark reconsideration of the 19th-century stoneware industry in the American South featuring more than 60 ceramic objects. Highlighting and celebrating African-American voices, the exhibition will address gaps in the narratives presented in art history. The exhibition also will include contemporary pieces by Simone Leigh, Theaster Gates, Robert Pruitt, and others. Intended Beneficiaries: The exhibition will serve participating artists, as well as Boston-area residents and visitors. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support an exhibition of the works of J.M.W. Turner. The exhibition will be the first to highlight Turner's (1775-1851) contemporary imagery, bringing together international loans and the MFA's of paintings, watercolors, drawings, and works-on-paper. Divided into sections, the exhibition will depict definitive interpretations of modern subjects, such as the transformation from sail to steam, as well as political reform and scientific and cultural advances that transformed society and shaped the modern world.

To support the exhibition "Fabric of a Nation: American Quilt Stories." The exhibition will revisit American history through 50 iconic bed covers largely drawn from the museum's collection. American stories from the colonial era to today will be central to the celebration of the museum's 150th year, which will highlight artists from underrepresented communities as well as women artists, in recognition of the Women's Suffrage Centennial.

To support the exhibition and public programming for "Matisse in the Studio." The exhibition will showcase the variety and diversity of Matisse's (1869-1954) collection of objects, which were both the subjects of his work and the catalyst for his extended creative process. The exhibition includes pots, vases, containers, textiles, paintings, sculptures, and works on paper by the artist. Public programming includes docent-led tours, in-gallery interactive discussions, lectures, courses led by curators, an audio guide, a free teacher workshop, and a family guide highlighting particular works and objects.

To support "Megacities Asia" with accompanying catalogue. The exhibition will feature contemporary artists from Seoul, Delhi, Mumbai, Beijing, and Shanghai including established artists such as Choi Jeong Hwa, Subodh Gupta, and Ai Wei Wei and emerging artists such as Asim Waqif and Aaditi Joshi. The artists' work reflects issues related to scarcity of natural resources, population explosions, and income inequality. A variety of activities is planned to fully engage the public.

To support the exhibition "Crafted: Objects in Flux," with accompanying catalogue. The exhibition will survey the international landscape of contemporary craft at a moment of transition - a time when artists are choosing skilled craft as a strategy for the production of contemporary works of art - simultaneously exploring and expanding the notion of what it means to make a crafted object. The exhibition will feature dozens of works of art across varied media by artists such as Sonya Clark and Greg Payce. The museum will collaborate with regional design schools to engage students through workshops and demonstrations by craft-based artists. Additionally, the exhibition will include several site-specific pieces by selected artists.

To support the Korean Collection Access Initiative. The two-pronged project will include publication of a collection catalogue and the reinstallation of the Museum's world-class Korean collection in a new 1,200 square foot gallery space.

To support photographic documentation of the museum's collection of three-dimensional Chinese objects. A component of the Museum's six-year effort to make its Chinese collection accessible worldwide, this phase of the project will document 1,500 unpublished holdings of glass, metalwork, porcelain, sculpture, lacquer, and glass.

To support staff costs associated with the reinstallation of the American Collection in the newly-constructed American Wing. Designed by architectural firm Foster and Partners, the new American wing will provide revitalized exhibition space for the museum's collection of important American paintings and decorative objects.

To support the publication of "Conservation" in the MFA Highlights series of guidebooks that explore areas of the museum's world-renowned encyclopedic permanent collection. This project will focus on the museum's conservation activities.

To support the publication of a newly developed, fully illustrated and innovative handbook which will widely expand the accessibility of the Museum of Fine Arts' encyclopedic collections and its local, national, and international audiences' understanding of the wide variety of major artworks in its holdings. Over the past two years, a cross-departmental team of MFA staff has been developing an innovative concept and design for a new type of handbook. The only handbook of the museum's collections now extant was designed in 1964 and was last printed in 1984. Many important works of art have entered the MFA's collections since, and the book's illustrations are almost all in black and white. The new handbook is projected to be 400 pages long and fully illustrated in color, presenting 400 of the museum's most important works in all media and from all historical periods and cultures. The project differs from other similar endeavors in that the book's text and design will be produced simultaneously, instead of the traditional process of producing a finished manuscript which is then passed on through an editor to designers who create the final product. Instead of segregating objects by medium and addressing them in isolation to each other, this new book will group art works in two-page spreads featuring three objects emphasizing their visual and contextual relationships.

Purpose: To support a research agenda and associated studies that will be designed and implemented by the East Boston Spatial Justice Lab. Additional Project Description: As a NEA Research Lab in the Arts, Health, and Social/Emotional Well-Being, the East Boston Spatial Justice Lab and its partner, Maverick Landing Community Services, will evaluate the arts' role in fostering community healing and social cohesion in East Boston, in addition to the well-being of community residents and their sense of belonging. The lab, which combines expertise in art, design, law, community organizing, and program evaluation, will execute a series of case studies and participatory action research methods to conduct and assess how community arts events emphasizing the values of belonging and social cohesion impact East Boston residents. These community arts-based workshops will include listening sessions, learning events, a speaker series, codesigning sessions, and town halls. Data will be collected through surveys, interviews, and focus groups. The team will share its findings and resources through a website and social media, academic publications and white papers, public presentations, open houses, public exhibits, and workshops. Additional partners include City Life/Vida Urbana, which is a grassroots community organization, and local artists and arts and cultural organizers. Future activities of the lab may extend to studies of the arts' impact on social community belonging and social cohesion as relevant to sectors such as public health, justice, and the environment. Intended Beneficiaries: This project will benefit community arts organizations, funders, planners, and developers who consult evidence-based practices for building social cohesion. Intended Outcome: Research, statistics, and general information about the arts benefit the arts sector and other fields.

To support a mixed-methods research study examining the impact of theater participation and arts-integrated peer leadership in the substance addiction recovery processes. In-depth interviews will be conducted with people who are in recovery from substance addiction and who have participated in the Phoenix Tales Recovery Storytelling workshops. Surveys will be given to similar participants and to current and former actors in the Improbable Players ensemble. In both cases, participants will reflect on the impact that theater participation has on their mental health and well-being in long-term recovery processes. Participants will engage in focus groups aimed to foster collaborations with researchers in interpreting the study findings.

To support the development of a five-year programming plan in relation to the organization's revised mission statement and transition to a new program structure. In conjunction with the celebration of its 20th anniversary in 1996, PRC initiated a year-long planning period to re-evaluate its mission in light of several factors of change: its 20-year lease with Boston University will end in 2003; changes in the photographic community in light of technological advances and the popularity of digital imagery; and changes in the arts funding climate. A new mission statement was adopted by the board in 1997 that significantly expands the Center's scope by recognizing photography's intersection with the practices of diverse professional fields and critical discourses, such as the x-ray to the medical profession or the aerial photograph to topography, for example. Concurrently, a new program structure was adopted that will present a narrative exhibition in two six-month segments plus four ten-week, guest-curated thematic exhibitions, each examining a specific issue raised by the narrative exhibitions. The board will identify individuals working outside the field of photography to serve as consultants in the development of a five-year programming plan.

Dozens of objects, including sketch and working models, maquettes, full-size casts, and bronze reductions, as well as enlarged photographs of finished monuments and memorials, will focus on French's classicized, idealized female figures. To support the dramatization of two radio plays based on the short stories of Sarah Orne Jewett and Edith Wharton as part of the radio drama series "Scribbling Women," distributed by National Public Radio "Scribbling Women" is a 12-part radio series of half-hour dramatizations of classic short stories by American women writers of the 19th an early 20th century. The programs are intended for general radio audiences, students of American literature, library discussion groups, adult education programs, high school teachers, community colleges, and agencies for the aging and visually impaired. Among the ten programs already completed for the series are Charlotte Perkins Stetson Gilman's The Yellow Wallpaper, Willa Cather's A Wagner Matinee, and Susan Glaspell's A Jury of Her Peers. Other writers in the series include Louisa May Alcott, Marita Bonner, Rebecca Harding Davis, Mary Eleanor Wilkins Freeman, Harriet A. Jacobs Caroline Kirkland, and Ann Petry. To complete the series, Edith Wharton's ghost story, Afterward, will be dramatized by playwright Laura Harrington and directed by Martin Jenkins. The sculpture will be located at the intersection of Chinatown, the Financial District, the Seaport, and the South Station transit hub in Boston.

To support "Playful Perspectives," an exhibition of large-scale, site-specific interactive public art works along the Rose Kennedy Greenway. Using scaled objects and optical illusions, artists will create whimsical work that challenges one's sense of perspective. Participating artists will include Meredith James, Mark A. Reigelman II, and Aakash Nihalani.

To support an aerial art installation designed by sculptor Janet Echelman. A public art project of suspended fluid net forms will unite the segmented parks and diverse communities over the length of the Greenway. The sculpture will be enhanced by lighting effects. Artist talks and an educational app for smart devices will provide additional insights into the sculpture's creation.

Organization Name: Society for the Preservation of New England Antiquities, Inc.
Project Description: To support a major exhibition titled "Cherished Possessions: A New England Legacy," with accompanying catalogue and education programs. For the first time in its 90-year history, SPNEA will prepare to tour its renowned collection of New England fine and decorative arts.

Purpose: To support a production of Fairview by Jackie Sibblies Drury. Additional Project Description: In Fairview, a family prepares for a birthday dinner celebrating its matriarch. Performed initially in the style of a television sitcom, the play drastically changes when a group of spectators steal control of the story and begin to comment on the action. An examination of voyeurism in art and entertainment, the play asks its audiences to challenge their own roles in the story. Intended Beneficiaries: The production will serve artists and residents in the greater Boston area. Intended Outcomes: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support SpeakEasy Stage Company's production of Once on This Island with music by Stephen Flaherty and book and lyrics by Lynn Ahrens. Additional Project Description: Based on the novel My Love, My Love; or, The Peasant Girl by Rosa Guy, the musical is about love and the barriers created by race and class. Produced in collaboration with Front Porch Arts Collective, and in partnership with the Huntington Community Membership Initiative, the project will offer significantly discounted tickets to community members who otherwise might not be able to attend. Through a partnership with MassHousing, students will attend matinee performances of the production. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit audiences in the greater Boston area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support a production of Pass Over by Antoinette Nwandu. The piece is a satirical reimagination of Samuel Beckett's Waiting for Godot, focused on two young men of color as they dream of ways to escape their circumstances. The theater will partner with Front Porch Arts Collective, an arts collective committed to combatting structural racism in Boston through theater, on the curation and facilitation of post-show audience conversations.

To support a production of "Violet" with book and lyrics by Brian Crawley and music by Jeanine Tesori. Set in 1964, and featuring a folk, rock, and gospel score, the musical tells the story of a young North Carolina woman who travels by bus to Tulsa to see a faith healer who she believes can transform her life. Directed by Producing Artistic Director Paul Daigneault, the production will feature performances by local gospel choirs, and will include student matinees and post-show discussion events.

To support a consortium project for the recording of a compact disc, a curriculum guide to accompany it, and a series of workshops by the Terezin Chamber Music Foundation based on the music written by composers imprisoned in the Theresienstadt concentration camp during World War II. This consortium project with Facing History and Ourselves will involve educational activiites to middle and high schools students in the Boston area and performances and teacher workshops in Boston, Chicago, Cleveland, Los Angeles, Memphis, New York and the San Francisco Bay area during 1999-2000.

Purpose: To support artist fees for the development and world premiere production of Fly, a new work based on the poetry of Marvin K. White. Additional Project Description: The work will explore the death of Marvin's friend Ricky, and how those who are left behind navigate loss and grief. The creators will work with artists from Double Edge Theatre to integrate movement into the piece. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit theater artists and audiences in Boston. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support the production of Amm(i)gone, a new play by Adil Mansoor. Additional Project Description: An autobiographical piece about Mansoor's relationship with their mother, the piece leverages Sophocles' Antigone as a starting point for a collaborative artistic process that explores the intersections of Islamophobia, sexism, ageism, racism, immigration, and queerness. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit theater artists and audiences in Greater Boston. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation’s cultural infrastructure.

Category: American Rescue Plan (ARP) Grants to Organizations
Project Description: Purpose: To support personnel, facilities, and marketing expenses in response to and recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. Additional Project Description: The support will help the organization maintain operations during recovery from the devastating economic and health effects of the COVID-19 pandemic. Intended Beneficiaries: This assistance will benefit the organization’s constituency, such as arts workers, artists, and audiences. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation’s cultural infrastructure.

To support staff salaries for the development and production of an original performance piece. Theater Offensive's advanced youth troupe, the Creative Action Crew, will create an original performance piece based on their lives as transgender and queer youth, under the guidance of ArtsEmerson's Co-Artistic Director P. Carl. The resulting production will be presented at ArtsEmerson. Audiences will be engaged in post-show analysis about the topics raised through forum theater techniques, discussions, and workshops.

Category: National Arts and Humanities Youth Program Awards
Project Description: In recognition of True Colors: Out Youth Theater. The longest running LGBT youth theater program in the country, it provides rigorous year-round intensive theater training, artistic, and leadership development programming for Boston's youth.

To support the creation of an online archive of the International Conference on Opportunities in the Arts. This international conference is a bridge between academic and real-world practice and helps local artists connect globally. The project will make the proceedings available to those unable to attend due to economic, geographic, physical, or other restrictions. Artists will benefit from information about how to launch careers abroad, work with new technologies, and engage with other cultures and non-art sectors.

To support free, online dissemination of the annual international Conference on Opportunities in the Arts. Post-conference information and content will be compiled, edited, and transmitted online via podcasts and transcripts to thousands of artists who could not attend the conference due to economic, geographic, physical, or other restrictions. This online format will allow any artist to have access to the conference's presentations by renowned artists, funders, critics, curators, and arts administrators. Artists will benefit from information about how to launch careers abroad, work with new technologies, and engage with other cultures and non-art sectors.

To support expansion of professional development resources for artists. The project will include updates to the organization's website allowing additional online services such as virtual portfolio reviews, podcasts, an interactive forum for exhibit postings, studio swaps, and job listings; an amplified marketing campaign; and a fourth biennale conference.

Purpose: To support the commission of a work by sculptor Hugh Hayden and a catalogue. Additional Project Description: The sculpture will be located on the grounds of the deCordova Sculpture Park and Museum in Lincoln, Massachusetts. A catalogue will be produced featuring works by Hugh Hayden (b. 1983). Intended Beneficiaries: Visitors to the deCordova Sculpture Park and Museum will benefit from the project. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Organization Name: Trustees of Tufts College, Tufts University School Of Medicine
Project Description: Purpose: To support a mixed-methods evaluation of the impact of co-designed public art installations on neighborhood residents' sense of cultural identity and social connectedness. Additional Project Description: The evaluation will focus on the Hudson Street Stoop Project, a rotating public art initiative in Boston's Chinatown District. For this initiative, each art installation is jointly designed by teams of local residents, public arts advisors, and artists. Researchers will conduct an evaluation, document the process for developing new art installations, and conduct surveys with stakeholders at various points during the co-design process. Once the artworks are installed, researchers will develop and administer surveys to residents. Through the surveys, the researchers will explore the social and emotional well-being of the residents, and the prospects for community healing and civic engagement. The researchers will compare the survey responses of people who interacted with the artwork with the survey responses from people who did not. The Asian Community Development Corporation is a partner on the project. Intended Beneficiaries: This study has the potential to benefit residents of the Boston Chinatown District as well as researchers and arts practitioners seeking to understand the benefit of public art installations on community cohesion. Intended Outcome: Evidence of the value and impact of the arts is expanded and promoted.

Category: National Arts and Humanities Youth Program Awards
Project Description: In recognition of Project ALERTA, for providing systematic early interventions in the form of out-of-school time enrichment programming to help third through fifth grade Latino and English-learning public school students in Boston, Massachusetts.

To support the creation of an endowment for the Arts Extension Service of the Division of Continuing Education at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst. For 25 years, first in New England, and nationally since the early 80s, Arts Extension Service(AES) has offered educational programs, consulting, services, research and publications that provide for the continuing education of artists, arts administrators and community leaders. AES has provided leadership and innovation to local arts leaders, including rural arts development, cultural planning, public art, craft development and arts in education partnerships. Increasingly AES is consulting and teaching for state and local arts agencies, national arts service agencies and funders. AES annually reaches more than 14,000 constituents, ranging from state and local arts agencies to town planning boards to individual artists. The small to mid-size arts organizations, especially those in rural and small communities are seldom able to pay the true costs of good program development, delivery and evaluation. AES regularly devotes a significant amount of time to unfunded research and program development.
